text:
As India's prime minister goes to China, Indians should learn that they have less to fear from their giant neighbour than they think
SOME comparisons are stark enough to generate a national inferiority complex. In 1980, India had about 687m people, 300m fewer than China. Living standards, as measured by purchasing power per head, were roughly the same. Then, as China embraced modernity with a sometimes ugly but burning passion, it left India behind. In the next 21 years, India outperformed its neighbour in almost nothing but population growth. 
By 2001, India had 1,033m people against China's 1,272m. But China's national income per head, according to the World Bank, was $890, nearly double India's $450. Adjusted for purchasing power, the Chinese were still 70% wealthier than Indians were. In the ten years from 1992, India's GDP per head grew at 4.3% a year, China's twice as fast. Some 5% of Chinese now live below the national poverty line, compared with 29% of Indians. 
Economic strength begets strategic clout. An accident of history made China one of the five permanent, veto-wielding members of the United Nations Security Council, but that seat now seems to belong to it as of right. India, feeling it should have one too, is just one of a number of big countries with a claim, and laments its comparative geopolitical weakness. As Raja Mohan writes in a new book on Indian foreign policy*, "In all the new comparisons between the two Asian neighbours who entered the modern world at around the same time, India appeared to fall behind in every single indicator of national power and social prosperity."
Many Indian businessmen, politicians and even diplomats now often ask westerners, in an aggrieved tone, why the West is so obsessed with China's economic success. But the obsession is India's, too. Comparison with China has become a distorting mirror in which Indians see their country's shortcomings grotesquely magnified. Many are looking at--often misunderstood--versions of the "Chinese model", to see what India can learn. 
For Indians, the "Chinese threat" comes in at least three forms: the geopolitical panic that rivalry with China may one day lead to another war between them; the economic nightmare of an India of underemployed farm labourers spending their meagre earnings on imported Chinese goods; and the ideological doubt that maybe India's heroic experiment with democracy has exacted an even higher price than has China's erratic dictatorship.
Bye-bye, Bhai Bhai
This was not the way Jawaharlal Nehru planned it. India's relations with China are still scarred by the bitterness that ended its first prime minister's dream of Hindi-Chini Bhai Bhai, Indo-Chinese brotherhood, sealed in a treaty in 1954. Sibling tension soon surfaced, and sharpened when India gave sanctuary in 1959 to the Dalai Lama and 100,000 of his followers as they fled China's suppression of an uprising in Tibet. It ended, in humiliating betrayal for Mr Nehru and India, in the war of 1962. 
In the late 1950s the Chinese army was found to have built a road across what India regarded as part of Ladakh, in its state of Jammu and Kashmir. It met Indian protests with a territorial claim of its own, far to the east, to what is now the state of Arunachal Pradesh. A brief war fought on three fronts resulted in a comprehensive Chinese victory. China invaded in the east, mostly for effect, before withdrawing a month later to the "line of actual control".
It took a quarter of a century for relations to return to something like normal. In 1988 the two prime ministers, Rajiv Gandhi and Li Peng, agreed to set the border dispute to one side. Since then there have been 14 meetings of a joint working group set up to tackle it. Although its energies have been directed mainly to deciding the extent of the dispute--ie, where the line of actual control should run--rather than solving it, the process has allowed what look like cordial relations to develop. Last year Zhu Rongji, then Chinese prime minister, came to India, and his Indian counterpart, Atal Behari Vajpayee, will repay the visit this weekend. On many international issues--such as the war in Iraq--the two countries agree. Bilateral trade has grown from a paltry $338m in 1992 to nearly $5 billion in 2002. 
At times, the mask of mutual respect slips. When India exploded a nuclear bomb in 1998, its defence minister, George Fernandes, let it be known that the arsenal was needed not so much because of Pakistan's nuclear ambitions as because of the long-term threat from China. It was certainly true that India's nuclear programme, started in the mid-1960s, was a response to its defeat in the 1962 war and to China's acquisition of the bomb two years later. Even this year, the present foreign minister, Yashwant Sinha, felt he needed to debunk theories of "the inevitability of conflict" between the two countries.
China's rapprochement with India has been complicated by its relations with Pakistan. Mr Vajpayee has now embarked on his "third and final" attempt to build a lasting peace with Pakistan, despite the two countries' dispute over Kashmir. He is hoping that China will be a moderating influence on Pakistan's generals. But with India still providing hospitality to the Dalai Lama, and China refusing to recognise India's incorporation of Sikkim in 1975 as a state of the Indian union, there is plenty besides the border wrangle to keep the two countries wary of each other.
Mr Mohan argues that, despite these remaining hang-ups, India is now ready for "comprehensive engagement" with China. For some Indian pundits, however, the clouds are still thick. In March, in India's Outlook magazine, Rajinder Puri analysed the peace process aimed at ending the Maoist rebellion in Nepal. His conclusion: "The Chinese plan to encircle India with its proxies is near completion." The Maoists, he said, had a "neat plan to make South Asia China's vassal." This is an extreme expression of what Uday Bhaskar, of the Institute of Defence Studies and Analyses in Delhi, says is undeniable: that "Chinese influence on the Indian periphery"--Pakistan, Bangladesh, Myanmar, Nepal and even Sri Lanka--has increased. 
A widely held belief colours Indian analysis of China's economic policies as well as its diplomacy: that Beijing has a grand and cunning plan, which survives all its political turmoil. India, in contrast, is an amiable, bumbling and inconsistent improviser. Mr Puri wound up his column with a little rhyme: "China moves events; India moves files. China never relents; India only smiles."
Tell me it isn't true
Many Indian businessmen and policymakers react to evidence of China's superior economic performance first with denial, and then with anger. Denial takes the form of an assault on the factual basis of the comparison: China, it is well known, stir-fries its books, and India, suffering in comparison, is the victim of geopolitical statistical fraud. The two Chinese numbers most subject to suspicion are, first, its spectacular GDP growth rates and, second, the gargantuan amounts of foreign direct investment (FDI) that China claims to attract.
It is true that both sets of figures are highly dubious. For many years, for example, China's growth figures simply have not added up: aggregated provincial data produce a higher annual growth rate than the national one (which, hardly inviting confidence, is usually published before the end of the year in question). Even some national data--on energy consumption, say, or freight volumes--are inconsistent with such rapid growth.
China's and India's relative success in attracting FDI represents the sharpest contrast of all between the two countries. According to the official data, China received $52.7 billion last year; India got just 4% of that amount, $2.3 billion. Again, some Indian economists have cried foul. India's figures are understated, they say, because they exclude foreigners' reinvested profits, the proceeds of foreign stockmarket listings, intra-company loans, trade credits, financial leases and so on. China's, on the other hand, are inflated by "round-tripping" of domestic investment through Hong Kong.
On both counts, there is little doubt that the statistics flatter China. Many economists argue that its growth figures overstate the truth by one or two percentage points. As for FDI, Sadhana Srivastava, in an article in India's Economic and Political Weekly, has recalculated both India's and China's figures for the year 2000 to make a fairer comparison. He found that China's FDI fell by half, while India's more than tripled. This meant that, as a percentage of GDP, there was not much difference: 1.7% for India against 2% for China.
However, even on this basis, India was still attracting just 40% of the amount of foreign investment that went to China. Much of the gap is attributable to the activities of overseas Chinese--in Taiwan, Hong Kong, South-East Asia and America. They have ploughed far more of their money back into the motherland than have non-resident Indians, despite Indians' economic success in many countries. 
Making things better
Nor, statistical quibbling aside, can there be much argument about the relative pace of growth fuelled by such investment. Some parts of India--Bangalore and Hyderabad, for example, or the industrial outskirts of Delhi--display the same feverish building that is under way in China. But in comparison with the massive construction site that is China's eastern seaboard, they seem like isolated pockets. China's growth may be patchy, localised and exaggerated. But all the evidence of the senses suggests that it is far faster than India's.
That is especially true of industrial growth, and above all of manufacturing, which in 2002 made up just 15% of India's GDP, compared with 35% of China's. Indian manufacturers scratch their heads in bafflement at China's ability to undercut them. Rahul Gupta, managing director of Phoenix Lamps, a lighting-products firm employing 1,300 people near Delhi, says that whenever he comes up against Chinese competition, he finds that the Chinese price is no more than the cost of Phoenix's raw materials. 
He blames this, in part, on hidden support in the form of subsidised raw materials; "huge amounts of unpaid receivables"; the absence of any concept of earning a return on capital invested; and export subsidies, which, in his business, he calculates to be worth 17% of the price. Phoenix, he says, simply cannot compete, and has retreated altogether from some products and some markets in Europe and South America. But customers, he thinks, will soon realise how shoddy Chinese products are. 
In a similar vein, another Indian firm, Paper Products, a Pune-based maker of packaging for big Indian companies and multinationals, sees, in the words of its boss, Suresh Gupta, "zero threat" from China. The Chinese, he says, are good at selling standardised commodities--which his company buys, causing grief for Indian suppliers--but are poor at "bespoke" products, such as unique packaging.
Both firms' experiences are commonplace. A report commissioned by the Confederation of Indian Industry, a national lobby organisation, sought to explode what it said were five widespread Indian myths about China: that its growth stems entirely from investment, not improvements in productivity; that manufacturing is driven primarily by exports; that low Chinese prices are the result of flawed accounting; that exports are priced more or less at cost; and that Chinese products are shoddy{dagger}. Indian industry, it seems, suffers from a curious mixture of panic and complacency about China.
The report found that neither is justified. It explains lower Chinese prices largely in terms of a tedious accumulation of minor cost disadvantages borne by Indian industry (see chart 2 on previous page). The biggest, accounting for as much as half the difference, are sales and excise taxes, followed by the cost of capital. India's much higher import duties--a trade-weighted average of around 24% compared with China's 13%--also push up the cost of inputs. The price of copper, for example, is 25% higher in India than in China.
If the report is right that the roots of Chinese manufacturing superiority lie in the fiscal and legal framework, that might worsen Indian industry's sense of inadequacy. But it also means that policy changes could do much to help India catch up: cutting import duties; simplifying and cutting indirect taxes by introducing a nationwide value-added tax (VAT); reducing the list of industries "reserved" for small companies; reforming the power industry by breaking down the state electricity boards into separate generation, transmission and distribution companies; easing labour laws to make hiring and firing and the use of contract workers easier. Indeed some of these reforms are already, slowly, under way, or at least under consideration.
But almost all of them are politically difficult. Bringing in a national VAT, for example, has been postponed three times, most recently this month, after state governments failed to lay the groundwork. In a number of places, the proposed tax was resisted by merchants, who shut shops in protest. With state and general elections looming, the government was loth to antagonise them. Not only do their votes matter; they can also be a vital source of party funds and, with their strike threats, of irritation to other voters. Typical, say reformists, of the political obstacles India faces.
China as a model?
"We must import either Chinese products", according to one gloomy Indian manufacturer, "or the Chinese model." Many Indians believe that a large part of the blame for their country's inferior economic performance must be borne by the political system. China, the argument goes, is a dictatorship where the government and the businesses it favours can do what they want--change laws, build infrastructure, secure licences, fiddle their books--all without brooking any opposition. In India, however, not only does every step require dealing with an inept, corrupt and intrusive bureaucracy, but the democratic system itself also imposes extra costs and delays. For every important and helpful reform, such as VAT, there is a powerful lobby that will oppose it.
Some make this argument in a spirit of pride: slower economic growth is a price worth paying for democratic freedom. For others it is an analysis of despair: what poor, backward India needs is less democracy and more discipline. 
Such a political comparison, however, contains many misperceptions. First, as those who have done business in China know, decision-making there is far less monolithic, far more ponderous, far more erratic and far more prone to profiteering by rent-seeking officials than it appears to some envious Indians. 
Second, much that holds India's economy and businesses back has little to do with democracy as such: corruption, fiscal mismanagement, a lack of international ambition and a history of over-protection at home. Where India overcomes these obstacles, and has a clear competitive advantage--as in software and other information-technology services--it can be a huge success. Indian firms such as Tata Consultancy Services and Wipro leave their Chinese rivals far behind, and are preparing to compete with the best multinationals.
The way India's democracy has evolved has undoubtedly complicated policymaking. Coalition governments give disproportionate power to regional and caste-based minority parties. Worse, the electoral timetable, with many important states holding polls between the national votes, tends to put governments into cautious, electioneering mode for much of their time in office.
Yet these handicaps should not be exaggerated. The political system does offer the hope that a party might aim over the heads of sectoral-interest groups to the aspirations of all Indians for a better life. Already, Indians have the enormous benefit of being able to turf out a government that performs appallingly. India may not have had a Communist Party-led boom, but nor has it endured a Cultural Revolution or a Great Leap Forward. Indians may also have the chance, one day, of being able to elect a government that does the right things. Some of them would involve, in Mr Mohan's phrase, moving from "envy to emulation" of China. In terms of the political system itself, however, the envy and emulation should go the other way.
*"Crossing the Rubicon: The Shaping of India's New Foreign Policy". Viking/Penguin Books India, 2003
{dagger} "Learning from China to unlock India's manufacturing potential". Confederation of Indian Industry and McKinsey, October 2002

Sibling tension soon surfaced , and sharpened when India gave sanctuary in 1959 to the Dalai Lama and 100,000 of his followers as they fled China 's suppression of an uprising in Tibet . It ended , in humiliating betrayal for Mr Nehru and India , in the war of 1962 . 
 In the late 1950s the Chinese army was found to have built a road across what India regarded as part of Ladakh , in its state of Jammu and Kashmir . It met Indian protests with a territorial claim of its own , far to the east , to what is now the state of Arunachal Pradesh . A brief war fought on three fronts resulted in a comprehensive Chinese victory . China invaded in the east , mostly for effect , before withdrawing a month later to the " line of actual control " . 
 It took a quarter of a century for relations to return to something like normal . In 1988 the two prime ministers , Rajiv Gandhi and Li Peng , agreed to set the border dispute to one side . Since then there have been 14 meetings of a joint working group set up to tackle it . Although its energies have been directed mainly to deciding the extent of the dispute -- ie , where the line of actual control should run -- rather than solving it , the process has allowed what look like cordial relations to develop . Last year Zhu Rongji , then Chinese prime minister , came to India , and Atal Bihari Vajpayee's , will repay the visit this weekend . On many international issues -- such as the war in Iraq -- the two countries agree . Bilateral trade has grown from a paltry $ 338 m in 1992 to nearly $ 5 billion in 2002 . 
 At times , the mask of mutual respect slips . When India exploded a nuclear bomb in 1998 , its defence minister , George Fernandes , let it be known that the arsenal was needed not so much because of Pakistan 's nuclear ambitions as because of the long - term threat from China . It was certainly true that India 's nuclear programme , started in the mid-1960s , was a response to its defeat in the 1962 war and to China 's acquisition of the bomb two years later . Even this year , the present foreign minister , Yashwant Sinha , felt he needed to debunk theories of " the inevitability of conflict " between the two countries . 
 China 's rapprochement with India has been complicated by its relations with Pakistan . Atal Bihari Vajpayee has now embarked on Atal Bihari Vajpayee's " third and final " attempt to build a lasting peace with Pakistan , despite the two countries ' dispute over Kashmir . Atal Bihari Vajpayee is hoping that China will be a moderating influence on Pakistan 's generals . But with India still providing hospitality to the Dalai Lama , and China refusing to recognise India 's incorporation of Sikkim in 1975 as a state of the Indian union , there is plenty besides the border wrangle to keep the two countries wary of each other . 
 Mr Mohan argues that , despite these remaining hang - ups , India is now ready for " comprehensive engagement " with China . For some Indian pundits , however , the clouds are still thick . In March , in India 's Outlook magazine , Rajinder Puri analysed the peace process aimed at ending the Maoist rebellion in Nepal . His conclusion : " The Chinese plan to encircle India with its proxies is near completion . " The Maoists , he said , had a " neat plan to make South Asia China 's vassal . " This is an extreme expression of what Uday Bhaskar , of the Institute of Defence Studies and Analyses in Delhi , says is undeniable : that " Chinese influence on the Indian periphery"--Pakistan , Bangladesh , Myanmar , Nepal and even Sri Lanka -- has increased . 
 A widely held belief colours Indian analysis of China 's economic policies as well as its diplomacy : that Beijing has a grand and cunning plan , which survives all its political turmoil . India , in contrast , is an amiable , bumbling and inconsistent improviser . Mr Puri wound up his column with a little rhyme : " China moves events ; India moves files . China never relents ; India only smiles . " 
 Tell me it is n't true 
 Many Indian businessmen and policymakers react to evidence of China 's superior economic performance first with denial , and then with anger . Denial takes the form of an assault on the factual basis of the comparison : China , it is well known , stir - fries its books , and India , suffering in comparison , is the victim of geopolitical statistical fraud . The two Chinese numbers most subject to suspicion are , first , its spectacular GDP growth rates and , second , the gargantuan amounts of foreign direct investment ( FDI ) that China claims to attract . 
 It is true that both sets of figures are highly dubious . For many years , for example , China 's growth figures simply have not added up : aggregated provincial data produce a higher annual growth rate than the national one ( which , hardly inviting confidence , is usually published before the end of the year in question ) . Even some national data -- on energy consumption , say , or freight volumes -- are inconsistent with such rapid growth . 
 China 's and India 's relative success in attracting FDI represents the sharpest contrast of all between the two countries . According to the official data , China received $ 52.7 billion last year ; India got just 4 % of that amount , $ 2.3 billion . Again , some Indian economists have cried foul . India 's figures are understated , they say , because they exclude foreigners ' reinvested profits , the proceeds of foreign stockmarket listings , intra - company loans , trade credits , financial leases and so on . China 's , on the other hand , are inflated by " round - tripping " of domestic investment through Hong Kong . 
 On both counts , there is little doubt that the statistics flatter China . Many economists argue that its growth figures overstate the truth by one or two percentage points . As for FDI , Sadhana Srivastava , in an article in India 's Economic and Political Weekly , has recalculated both India 's and China 's figures for the year 2000 to make a fairer comparison . He found that China 's FDI fell by half , while India 's more than tripled . This meant that , as a percentage of GDP , there was not much difference : 1.7 % for India against 2 % for China . 
 However , even on this basis , India was still attracting just 40 % of the amount of foreign investment that went to China . Much of the gap is attributable to the activities of overseas Chinese -- in Taiwan , Hong Kong , South - East Asia and America . They have ploughed far more of their money back into the motherland than have non - resident Indians , despite Indians ' economic success in many countries . 
 Making things better 
 Nor , statistical quibbling aside , can there be much argument about the relative pace of growth fuelled by such investment . Some parts of India -- Bangalore and Hyderabad , for example , or the industrial outskirts of Delhi -- display the same feverish building that is under way in China . But in comparison with the massive construction site that is China 's eastern seaboard , they seem like isolated pockets . China 's growth may be patchy , localised and exaggerated . But all the evidence of the senses suggests that it is far faster than India 's . 
 That is especially true of industrial growth , and above all of manufacturing , which in 2002 made up just 15 % of India 's GDP , compared with 35 % of China 's . Indian manufacturers scratch their heads in bafflement at China 's ability to undercut them . Rahul Gupta , managing director of Phoenix Lamps , a lighting - products firm employing 1,300 people near Delhi , says that whenever he comes up against Chinese competition , he finds that the Chinese price is no more than the cost of Phoenix 's raw materials . 
 He blames this , in part , on hidden support in the form of subsidised raw materials ; " huge amounts of unpaid receivables " ; the absence of any concept of earning a return on capital invested ; and export subsidies , which , in his business , he calculates to be worth 17 % of the price . Phoenix , he says , simply can not compete , and has retreated altogether from some products and some markets in Europe and South America . But customers , he thinks , will soon realise how shoddy Chinese products are . 
 In a similar vein , another Indian firm , Paper Products , a Pune - based maker of packaging for big Indian companies and multinationals , sees , in the words of its boss , Suresh Gupta , " zero threat " from China . The Chinese , he says , are good at selling standardised commodities -- which his company buys , causing grief for Indian suppliers -- but are poor at " bespoke " products , such as unique packaging . 
 Both firms ' experiences are commonplace . A report commissioned by the Confederation of Indian Industry , a national lobby organisation , sought to explode what it said were five widespread Indian myths about China : that its growth stems entirely from investment , not improvements in productivity ; that manufacturing is driven primarily by exports ; that low Chinese prices are the result of flawed accounting ; that exports are priced more or less at cost ; and that Chinese products are shoddy{dagger } . Indian industry , it seems , suffers from a curious mixture of panic and complacency about China . 
 The report found that neither is justified . It explains lower Chinese prices largely in terms of a tedious accumulation of minor cost disadvantages borne by Indian industry ( see chart 2 on previous page ) . The biggest , accounting for as much as half the difference , are sales and excise taxes , followed by the cost of capital . India 's much higher import duties -- a trade - weighted average of around 24 % compared with China 's 13%--also push up the cost of inputs . The price of copper , for example , is 25 % higher in India than in China . 
 If the report is right that the roots of Chinese manufacturing superiority lie in the fiscal and legal framework , that might worsen Indian industry 's sense of inadequacy . But it also means that policy changes could do much to help India catch up : cutting import duties ; simplifying and cutting indirect taxes by introducing a nationwide value - added tax ( VAT ) ; reducing the list of industries " reserved " for small companies ; reforming the power industry by breaking down the state electricity boards into separate generation , transmission and distribution companies ; easing labour laws to make hiring and firing and the use of contract workers easier . Indeed some of these reforms are already , slowly , under way , or at least under consideration . 
 But almost all of them are politically difficult . Bringing in a national VAT , for example , has been postponed three times , most recently this month , after state governments failed to lay the groundwork . In a number of places , the proposed tax was resisted by merchants , who shut shops in protest . With state and general elections looming , the government was loth to antagonise them . Not only do their votes matter ; they can also be a vital source of party funds and , with their strike threats , of irritation to other voters . Typical , say reformists , of the political obstacles India faces . 
 China as a model ? 
 " We must import either Chinese products " , according to one gloomy Indian manufacturer , " or the Chinese model . " Many Indians believe that a large part of the blame for their country 's inferior economic performance must be borne by the political system . China , the argument goes , is a dictatorship where the government and the businesses it favours can do what they want -- change laws , build infrastructure , secure licences , fiddle their books -- all without brooking any opposition . In India , however , not only does every step require dealing with an inept , corrupt and intrusive bureaucracy , but the democratic system itself also imposes extra costs and delays . For every important and helpful reform , such as VAT , there is a powerful lobby that will oppose it . 
 Some make this argument in a spirit of pride : slower economic growth is a price worth paying for democratic freedom . For others it is an analysis of despair : what poor , backward India needs is less democracy and more discipline . 
 Such a political comparison , however , contains many misperceptions . First , as those who have done business in China know , decision - making there is far less monolithic , far more ponderous , far more erratic and far more prone to profiteering by rent - seeking officials than it appears to some envious Indians . 
 Second , much that holds India 's economy and businesses back has little to do with democracy as such : corruption , fiscal mismanagement , a lack of international ambition and a history of over - protection at home . Where India overcomes these obstacles , and has a clear competitive advantage -- as in software and other information - technology services -- it can be a huge success . Indian firms such as Tata Consultancy Services and Wipro leave their Chinese rivals far behind , and are preparing to compete with the best multinationals . 
 The way India 's democracy has evolved has undoubtedly complicated policymaking . Coalition governments give disproportionate power to regional and caste - based minority parties . Worse , the electoral timetable , with many important states holding polls between the national votes , tends to put governments into cautious , electioneering mode for much of their time in office . 
 Yet these handicaps should not be exaggerated . The political system does offer the hope that a party might aim over the heads of sectoral - interest groups to the aspirations of all Indians for a better life . Already , Indians have the enormous benefit of being able to turf out a government that performs appallingly . India may not have had a Communist Party - led boom , but nor has it endured a Cultural Revolution or a Great Leap Forward . Indians may also have the chance , one day , of being able to elect a government that does the right things . Some of them would involve , in Mr Mohan 's phrase , moving from " envy to emulation " of China . In terms of the political system itself , however , the envy and emulation should go the other way . 
 * " Crossing the Rubicon : The Shaping of India 's New Foreign Policy " . Viking / Penguin Books India , 2003

 Caption : Democracies can excel , too

text:
A genial summit
JUST five years ago, India's defence minister described China as India's biggest threat. The visit to China this week of Atal Behari Vajpayee, the first by an Indian head of government in a decade, suggests a thaw is well under way.
No one was expecting Mr Vajpayee's six-day tour, due to end on June 27th, to make any dramatic breakthrough on the main point of contention, namely the delineation of the 2,200 mile (3,500km) common border. This dispute, aggravated by India's harbouring of Tibet's exiled leader, the Dalai Lama, triggered a brief war in 1962. But the two sides have now appointed senior officials to pep up negotiations. They also expressed eagerness to work on other aspects of the relationship, especially trade. Though rapidly expanding, this amounted to a mere $5 billion last year, compared with $97 billion between China and America, according to China's figures.
The two sides agreed to a new border crossing for trade between Tibet and the Himalayan territory of Sikkim, which India annexed in 1975. China has never recognised India's claim to Sikkim, but the agreement could be construed as a tacit recognition by China that Sikkim is part of India. For its part, India referred to Tibet in writing as the Tibet Autonomous Region--China's name for it--which the Chinese claimed was the first time India had explicitly recognised the "autonomous region" as part of China. Both sides insisted their positions had not really changed, though on such sensitive issues, that was no surprise.
India's cosying up to China is unlikely to have much impact on China's close relationship with Pakistan. China may have adopted a more neutral position on the Kashmir issue in recent years, but it still sees Pakistan as an important ally--partly as a buffer against India but also because a hostile Pakistan would be well placed to stir up trouble among restive Muslims in China's far west. Mr Vajpayee did complain that Pakistan was not doing enough to curb insurgents in Kashmir. But not a word has been uttered in public, at least, about China's military aid to Pakistan, including what India suspects was covert support for Pakistan's nuclear-weapons programme. India is not about to let that old grievance ruin a blossoming friendship.
Caption: Everybody needs good neighbours

text:
Not yet peace, but something like it
IT ALMOST feels like the old days in Srinagar, the summer capital of the disputed Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir where at least 40,000 people have been killed since an insurgency began 14 years ago. Tourists have returned. Nearly 70,000 have come in the past six months to stay in houseboats on the city's Dal Lake and tour the surrounding mountains, more than double the number in the whole of last year. Troops are slightly less evident in the streets, and the government will soon sanction a mobile-phone service that has been denied for years by security fears. Moderate separatist leaders, as well as mainstream politicians, are talking more positively than before about the need for an end to militancy. People, they say, need to begin to rebuild their lives.
Mehbooba Mufti, president of the People's Democratic Party, which has led the state's coalition government since last October, credits the change partly to a visit in April by Atal Behari Vajpayee, India's prime minister, when he offered a "hand of friendship" to Pakistan. The "jinx was broken," says Ms Mehbooba. An unprecedented three-day visit to the state last weekend by India's relaxed president, A.P.J. Abdul Kalam (above), also "brought a sense of belonging and security."
But real peace is a long way off. On the day in June when Mr Kalam visited the border that separates Indian and Pakistani Kashmir, known as the line of control (LoC), 12 Indian soldiers were killed in a suicide attack on an army camp at Sunjwan, near Jammu, 400km (250 miles) to the south. The attack triggered memories of the killing of 34 people, soldiers and members of their families, in May last year, when India and Pakistan came close to war. But militants frequently stage atrocities to coincide with important visits, and the government reacted relatively calmly.
George Fernandes, India's defence minister, claimed that Pakistan's Inter-Services Intelligence agency was responsible for the attack, which Pakistan denied. But Mr Vajpayee's peace moves would continue. Senior Indian army and police officers say that militants continue to cross into Indian Kashmir from Pakistan, but they believe that Pakistan is trying to curb major terrorist attacks. The question for India is what it should do next to bring permanent peace. There is a growing desire among Kashmiris for an end to the killings, but also for some autonomy from India's central government. 
The neatest solution would be for Pakistan to accept the LoC, agreed between the two countries in 1972, as the permanent border and for India to restore to Kashmir most of the high degree of regional autonomy that it had for six years after India gained independence in 1947.
But Pakistan says it seeks all of Kashmir, which has a Muslim majority, and India has never seemed willing to move on the autonomy issue. Many observers believe India would prefer to tolerate unrest, and even terrorism, and keep the LoC as a de facto border, rather than risk a settlement that might give ground to Pakistan and the Kashmiri militants whom it supports. 
Significantly, the Pakistan-backed All-Party Hurriyat Conference, a group of 23 Kashmir-based parties with separatist roots, did not greet Mr Kalam with the day-long hartal (strike) they usually call when Indian leaders visit. This was seen to reflect growing moderation in a group that is struggling to re-establish its diminished credibility. Abdul Gani Bhat, the Hurriyat's chairman, says that "the noise of politics has taken over from the role of the gun." Mirwaiz Omar Farooq, a young religious leader and political leader, wants militants to "take a back seat" but "remain a pressure group".
Privately, some Hurriyat members indicate that they would drop demands for independence or a Pakistan takeover if some form of autonomy were offered by Delhi, perhaps implemented in stages over several years. But they face opposition from hardliners and are assumed to be hobbled by Pakistan, and by the lesson of two leading moderates who have been assassinated in the past 13 months.
The Indian government shuns the Hurriyat, claiming its leaders are unrepresentative, even though they reflect a large body of Kashmiri opinion. It prefers to deal only with the state's mainstream parties, which do not press the autonomy issue aggressively. Mr Bhat will be visiting Delhi later this month with Mr Farooq, seeking a "dialogue that will give real results", but he seems unlikely to make much progress with the government. He predicted that "within a couple of years we'll be back to normalisation of relations between India and Pakistan," with "the resolution of the situation in Kashmir". That shows rare optimism but, as Miss Saeed put it, "people are in a mood for change and, if we don't respond, then we miss the bus. There can't be a better chance than this."

text:
A political battle over Rupert Murdoch's Star TV
EACH Wednesday night in recent weeks, Star News, a Hindi language TV news channel produced in India by an offshoot of Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, has had to obtain the Indian government's permission to broadcast for the next seven days via its regional base in Hong Kong. This ritual will continue until Star News comes to terms with the government over its ownership, and satisfies critics that its Indian equity partners are not cronies there to do Mr Murdoch's bidding. When a deal is eventually done, Star will have a ten-year licence to take its news programmes direct from its base in Mumbai.
The dispute is complicated by Indian business rivals and sympathetic politicians lobbying the government on an issue that has reached the office of the prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee. In full-page newspaper ads on July 21st, Star complained of "a mix of vested interests, commercial pressures and competitive agenda" and a "media campaign aimed to confuse and mislead people".
Star India, wholly owned by News Corp, is now the market leader. Star Plus, a Hindi entertainment channel, has 45 of the top 50 programmes and 56m viewers--its main Indian-owned rival, Zee TV, has 33m. The market share of Star News, which gave up English language programmes nearly four months ago, has soared from 7% to 30%. Zee News has dropped from 25% to 17%; Aaj Tak, another news channel, has gone from over 60% to 37%. Subhash Chandra, who controls Zee Telefilms and was once Mr Murdoch's joint-venture partner, is widely believed to be using links inside Mr Vajpayee's Bharatiya Janata Party to lobby against Star. India Today, a weekly news magazine within the Indian group that owns Aaj Tak, has run critical articles--the latest headlining Mr Murdoch as "Boss of the World".
India changed its TV news rules last March, limiting any foreign partner to 26% of the equity, in line with newspaper ownership rules. But it did not repeat the newspaper rule that 51% of the equity must be held by a single Indian investor. Star has spread remaining shares in its editorial firm, Media Content and Commercial Services, among six apparently friendly Indian investors. This has led to accusations that News Corp will be the dominant influence behind the scenes, as it is in its FM radio operations.
Star News may yet be required to lock in an Indian investor with at least a 26% stake, to restrict changes of ownership, or to get a single 51% Indian investor. This has led to speculation that Mr Murdoch might find a powerful local business partner--maybe Shobhana Bhartia, who runs the Hindustan Times, part of a large industrial group controlled by her father, K.K. Birla. At least that might help to insulate the world's best-known media baron from further concerted attacks as his Star rises.
Caption: A message from Murdoch

text:
China detains an Indian patrol
TRIPS to China by Atal Behari Vajpayee, India's prime minister, seem to be jinxed. In 1979, when he was India's foreign minister, he had to cut short a visit to Beijing when China invaded Vietnam. Now it has emerged that, during a trip to China in June, when he signed a "comprehensive co-operation" agreement, an Indian security patrol was being detained by Chinese troops on the mountainous border between India's north-eastern state of Arunachal Pradesh and China. 
The diplomatic flap since this confrontation was leaked in an Indian newspaper on July 24th illustrates the two countries' brittle relationship. India initially tried to maintain the spirit of the Vajpayee visit and responded less bluntly. But this week a government spokesman said that Arunachal's status was a "historical fact that cannot be changed by anyone". India's External Affairs Ministry formally summoned a senior Chinese diplomat in Delhi to complain that the Indian patrol's treatment breached a 1993 "peace and tranquillity" agreement that there would be no aggressive acts when patrols met. 
"A little bit of toughness is needed and if that leads to them saying 'no border talks', then fine," says J.N. Dixit, a former Indian foreign secretary, who believes that India should deal robustly when challenged by its dominant neighbour. Such an escalation is unlikely because the main focus of the Vajpayee visit, apart from boosting trade, was to begin to tackle differences on the two countries' 4,000 km (2,500 miles) mostly-disputed border, known as the "line of actual control" (LAC). In the west, India claims a remote mountainous area called Aksai Chin (38,000 square kilometres), which China occupied in its 1962 war against India and regards as strategically important. There are also numerous small pockets of disputed territory.

Equally, a trade-off, with the LAC becoming permanent, would not be acceptable to India because it lost Aksai Chin in the 1962 war. Overall, India is in more of a hurry than China to fix the border because it would like to move troops to its more volatile frontier with Pakistan. text:
The mood music is sweeter; but hostility is just an atrocity away
AS IN any feuding family, at times there is a clamour to let bygones be bygones. Indians and Pakistanis, separated at birth 56 years ago, have in recent weeks been warmed by the memory of how much they share, rather than, as so often, chilled by the fear of another war. But so far there is more sentiment than substance to the mood of reconciliation.
The latest appeal for constructive amnesia came from Pakistan's president, Pervez Musharraf, on August 12th. "Forget Kargil," he said, in reference to a small war in 1999, sparked by a Pakistani military adventure, at a time when he was merely the army chief, instead of combining the job, as he does now, with running the country. General Musharraf added an offer of a ceasefire, in which the two armies would stop shelling each other across the "line of control" dividing Kashmir. But three explosions in Indian Kashmir the next day were a reminder that such a ceasefire would not stop the violence.
General Musharraf was speaking in Islamabad after meeting an Indian delegation, including 34 members of Parliament, that formed part of a recent flowering of "people-to-people" diplomacy. Some of the people are unexpected. The star of the Indian team was Laloo Prasad Yadav, former chief minister of the notoriously misgoverned state of Bihar and now husband to the incumbent. He faces corruption charges, and India's Supreme Court had to order prosecutors to return his passport for the trip. But his folksy style--he champions India's lower castes--went down a treat in Pakistan, where politicians are almost invariably patrician, bearded or in uniform.
Of the bearded clerics, Fazlur Rehman has emerged as an unlikely proponent of reconciliation. He heads an alliance of six religious parties that leads Pakistan's opposition. Mr Rehman also paid a much-publicised peace-mongering trip of his own to India last month.
This flurry of "track two"--unofficial--diplomacy followed the offer in April by India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, of the "hand of friendship" to Pakistan. This was doubly surprising: twice before Mr Vajpayee has extended his hand, only to have it bitten (once at Kargil, and once at a summit in Agra); moreover, a hard line towards Pakistan was widely seen as popular in India. 
Yet the prime minister seems to have judged the public mood well. Two stories of cross-border humanitarianism have particularly warmed hearts. Last month, Noor Fatima, a two-year-old Pakistani girl, was treated to heart surgery in the Indian city of Bangalore. And this week, a 13-year-old boy, picked up in India in June after inadvertently straying across the border, was bused back to Pakistan.
The reopening of that bus route was itself evidence of improved relations. Air links, which were also severed after a terrorist attack on India's Parliament in December 2001, may also be resumed soon. Already full diplomatic relations are restored. But, these achievements aside, "track one", or official, diplomacy is largely non-existent. There have been no ministerial, let alone summit, meetings between India and Pakistan since before the Delhi attack.
India's immediate dismissal of General Musharraf's ceasefire proposal implies official talks will have to wait. India wants any ceasefire in Kashmir tied to a halt to the cross-border infiltration of Pakistan-based militants, which, it says, continues unabated. Its diplomats believe that, while Pakistan does want closer economic ties, General Musharraf remains hostage to Islamists and his own army. These two forces, intimately linked, will never tolerate any softening of Pakistan's claim to Kashmir, and may eventually sabotage any improvement in relations.
Pakistan's deep-rooted suspicions are the precise mirror image: that all Mr Vajpayee's friendly rhetoric is empty, designed to fob Pakistan off without engaging it on the core of the dispute, Kashmir. As violence continues there, an abrupt end to the current friendly atmosphere could occur at any moment.

text:
Another terrorist massacre in India has raised old questions about Pakistan and Hindu-Muslim relations
THE co-ordinated terrorist onslaught on August 25th on Mumbai, India's commercial capital, was devastating. Two bombs, planted in taxis, exploded within minutes of each other at lunchtime, in parts of the city thronged with office-workers, shopkeepers, sightseers, hawkers and beggars. More than 50 people were killed. The longer-term consequences of this remain murky. At worst, the atrocity might spark a new round of communal blood-letting in India itself, and plunge India's thawing relations with Pakistan back into the icy depths.
The first signs were less discouraging on both fronts. Mumbai's citizens responded to the bombs with fortitude, and with more communal solidarity than antagonism. Within a day, the streets were crowded, the traffic jammed and the stockmarket, after a knee-jerk tumble, had staged an impressive rally. In Pakistan, meanwhile, both the foreign ministry and a leading Islamist party were quick to condemn the slaughter. India refrained from immediate finger-pointing. Talks in Islamabad on resuming air links--severed after an earlier terrorist attack, on the parliament in Delhi in December 2001--went ahead as scheduled on August 27th.
However, India's deputy prime minister, L. K. Advani, a hardliner in the ruling, Hindu nationalist, Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), was less restrained. He portrayed the bombings as part of "our neighbour's war of terrorism against us", which, he said, was not limited to Kashmir. Some Muslims were outraged at such a provocative accusation made so prematurely, and without supporting evidence.
The police's prime suspects are affiliates of a banned Indian organisation, known as SIMI (Student Islamic Movement of India), and of Lashkar-e-Taiba, a Pakistan-based militant Islamist group, dedicated to the "liberation" of Indian-ruled Kashmir. The police link the attacks to five other bombings in Mumbai in the past eight months. 
The driver of one of the latest bomb-carrying taxis survived, and so the police have some information about his passengers, the presumed culprits. But the timing of the latest bombings, and the absence of any claim of responsibility, have given rise to all manner of theories. It was noticed, for example, that they closely followed similar car bombings in Jakarta, Baghdad and the Caucasus. Lashkar has known al-Qaeda links--a senior al-Qaeda member was arrested at one of its houses in Pakistan--but India's counter-terrorist police are not blaming Osama bin Laden for this attack, except perhaps as a role model.
The bombing also preceded by two days a visit to Kashmir by the prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, for a meeting of chief ministers from Indian states. It was meant to flaunt the region's new-found "stability", but was greeted by a series of violent incidents before it opened.
Most strikingly, the Mumbai bombs went off just hours after reports that archaeologists had found some evidence of a tenth-century Hindu temple beneath the site of the 16th-century Babri mosque in the northern town of Ayodhya. The destruction of that mosque in December 1992, by Hindu fanatics, prompted some of India's worst communal violence. However, most observers think the bombing was too well planned to have been an instant response to this boost for Hindu nationalism's most cherished cause. 
The police's initial theory is that it was planned by SIMI associates based in Sharjah and Dubai, and that Pakistan's intelligence service, the ISI, may have had a hand. Based partly on the interrogation of 21 people arrested in connection with the earlier bombings (and assuming that the latest bombs are a continuation of them), they blame a campaign of retribution for last year's anti-Muslim pogrom in the state of Gujarat. Up to 2,000 people were killed, and there is evidence of official connivance in the violence. Mumbai's terrorists' targets have been areas with large Gujarati populations. 
The random slaughter of rich and poor, old and young, Muslim and Hindu is a cruel, haphazard way to exact revenge. But Mumbai's residents have seen it before. On March 12th 1993, 257 people were killed by ten co-ordinated bombs. India blamed the ISI, acting through Mumbai's leading Muslim gangster, Dawood Ibrahim, and other thugs. They were allegedly also taking reprisals for anti-Muslim communal rioting: the killing of more than 900 people in Mumbai following the destruction of the Ayodhya mosque the previous year.
The unfulfilled mission of the destroyers--to build a temple on the site they say marks the birthplace of Ram, a model king and incarnate deity--has haunted Indian politics ever since, poisoning communal relations between Hindus and the Muslim minority. Even the Gujarat violence was related to it: it followed the burning to death of several dozen Hindu activists on a train from Ayodhya. 
The archaeologists' report was ordered by the court hearing an ownership dispute--which has been under way since 1949--about the site in Ayodhya. The reaction of interested parties quickly showed it would do little to end the argument. Muslim groups denied it showed evidence of a temple. But the findings will strengthen those voices in the BJP arguing that the government should legislate for the construction of a temple, and that this should become part of its campaign for next year's general elections.
By the same token, with important state as well as national elections looming, some Indian politicians--such as Mr Advani--may think Pakistan-bashing is a vote-winner. He has already reverted to India's claim (which Pakistan denies) that 19 known terrorists, including Dawood Ibrahim and other alleged perpetrators of the 1993 bombings, are living in Pakistan under ISI patronage. He argues that, until they are handed over, Pakistan's condolences over this week's bloodshed cannot be taken as sincere. 
Tension with Pakistan may suit some Indian politicians. But many analysts believe the ISI, too, has an institutional interest of it own in thwarting reconciliation with India. On both sides of the border, the rapprochement of the past few months has been broadly welcomed. But it may not be as resilient as Mumbai's business-as-usual signs.

text:
A war of many battlefields
BLESSED with non-stop television news, India is cursed by depressing pictures to fill it. Last weekend they included live coverage of a siege and shoot-out in Srinagar, summer capital of the Indian-controlled state of Jammu and Kashmir. One of those killed by the security forces was later identified as "Ghazi Baba". His death had an immediate--and bloody--impact in Kashmir. But for India it was a triumph in its anti-terrorist war, which this week intensified on a number of fronts.
Ghazi Baba was allegedly the commander in Indian Kashmir for Jaish-e-Mohammad, an extremist Islamist group fighting for the area's incorporation into Pakistan. India calls him the "mastermind" of a number of atrocities, notably murderous attacks in 2001 on the state assembly in Srinagar and the Parliament in Delhi. 
That was not the only success claimed by India's security forces this week. On September 1st, four people were arrested for involvement in a two-bomb attack in Mumbai a week earlier, in which 52 people were killed. The arrests seemed to bolster police theories about the crime: that, like five other, smaller bombings in Mumbai since last December, it was perpetrated by Muslims in revenge for communal violence in the state of Gujarat last year; that much of the planning had been undertaken in Dubai; and that there were links with another extremist group, Lashkar-e-Taiba, and, through it, with the Pakistani intelligence services. 
Those detained, however, were depicted as "foot-soldiers"--bomb-planters deployed by more sinister conspirators. The police believe Mumbai was not the only target; the plan was for co-ordinated attacks in more than one city. On August 30th, a huge stash of explosives was discovered at Delhi's main railway station.
Surprisingly, this evidence of a concerted terrorist onslaught on Indian civilians did not provoke the usual diatribes against the terrorists' supposed sponsors in Pakistan. Instead, Indian officials privately suggested that the slow crawl towards normalised relations--initiated by India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, in April--would be allowed to continue, at least for the time being. Pakistan's arrest this week of three army officers with alleged links to terrorist groups may help.
But "normalisation" should not be mistaken for a peace process. Mr Vajpayee has ruled out high-level talks while the violence continues. And, supporting Indian boasts about his importance, Ghazi Baba's death unleashed a new wave of violence in Kashmir. More than 30 people died on the first three days of September. Parts of the main highway linking the north and south of the state were blown up.
Against this backdrop, the prospect of talks between separatist groups and the Indian government has faded. Moderate separatists seem to have been eclipsed. A 14-year old insurgency, which poisons relations with Pakistan and brings the scourge of terrorism to television screens and cities, has been resumed in earnest. It is all depressingly familiar.

text:
A riot 11 years ago still roils Indian politics 
THE Babri mosque in Ayodhya in the north-Indian state of Uttar Pradesh is no more, but it still casts a long shadow. It was demolished by a mob of Hindu fanatics in 1992 because they believed it trespassed on the birthplace of the divine king Ram. Ever since, whenever India has been scarred by large-scale communal violence, it has often been traced back to the wound left by that episode, and its unfinished business: the glorious new Ram temple devotees want to build on the site. The issue may also still fuel a power struggle among the leaders of India's ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), and the "family" of Hindu-nationalist organisations to which it belongs.
On October 10th, seven of those leaders will be formally charged for their alleged parts in the 1992 riot. They include Murli Manohar Joshi, the minister for human-resource development, and Uma Bharti, the BJP's candidate for chief minister in the important state of Madhya Pradesh, where elections are due to be held in November. But they exclude the man most associated with the mass campaign that culminated in the dismantling of the mosque: L.K. Advani, now India's deputy prime minister.
Mr Advani was also facing charges from the Central Bureau of Investigation. But the CBI's case against him was curiously flawed and, on September 19th, a court in Uttar Pradesh dismissed it. text:
Peace moves from India put Pakistan on the defensive
IT LOOKED like the festive spirit. On October 22nd, just ahead of the biggest Hindu holiday, Diwali, a time for families and gift-giving, India produced a sackful of goodies for its neighbours and enemies. First came an announcement that the deputy prime minister, L.K. Advani, was willing to talk to separatists in Kashmir. Within hours there followed the unveiling of an offer of 12 practical steps towards improved relations with Pakistan. Both acts of generosity are of course calculated and not as open-hearted as they seem. But they are startling nonetheless, and even hold some promise.
Mr Advani's agreement to talk to the All-Party Hurriyat Conference, an umbrella group of separatist parties in the Indian-controlled part of Kashmir, marks an about-turn. The government had a standing offer of talks, but with its designated "interlocutor", N.N. Vohra, a retired civil servant. The Hurriyat insisted on high-level political talks, and the inclusion of Pakistan, which claims Kashmir as its own, in the dialogue.
Last month, however, the Hurriyat split over its approach to negotiations with India. Of its 25 constituents, 13 broke away into a new hard-line group under the leadership of Syed Ali Shah Geelani. Many saw the hand of India's intelligence services in the machinations that led to the fissure. India's offer is directed at the moderate rump of the Hurriyat, chaired by Maulana Abbas Ansari. Mr Geelani at once rebuffed India's offer. Mr Ansari's supporters, however, were at least prepared to discuss it.
India's new approach may be partly inspired by a recent upsurge in violence in Kashmir, now in one of the bloodier phases of its 14-year insurgency. India probably hopes to entrench the divisions in the Hurriyat. Kashmiri politicians give warning that this might be counter-productive, enabling hard-liners to portray the moderates India needs to cultivate as quislings. But India also wants to keep up the pressure on Pakistan, which it accuses of training, arming and encouraging terrorists in Kashmir. It also hopes that America will come to see Pakistan less as a vital ally in its war against al-Qaeda and the Taliban, and more as a state sponsor of anti-Indian terrorism.
Similarly, the offer of improved relations with Pakistan is also intended to impress Indian and foreign opinion that India is not to blame for continued tension between two nuclear powers, which last year seemed at times on the verge of war. The most dramatic proposal is the least likely to be accepted. India has suggested that a bus link be opened across the "line of control" that divides the Pakistani and Indian parts of Kashmir. India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, earlier this month restated India's claim to the Pakistani part. But India, ultimately, would probably accept the line of control as its international border. Legalising cross-border travel might help formalise that, which is why Pakistan is likely to reject it, popular as it would be in the divided region.
Many of the other ideas promote "people-to-people contacts", which have been expanding since April, when Mr Vajpayee launched his latest peace initiative in a speech in Kashmir. Pakistan will welcome most measures, while regretting that India is still not offering to talk about the dispute at the heart of the two countries' long enmity: Kashmir.
Most important to many Indians and Pakistanis, India has offered to renew sporting ties. Cricket, especially, is a cross-border national obsession. India is also suggesting new transport links to add to the over-booked bus service between Delhi and Lahore, including a ferry from Mumbai to Karachi, and the restoration of air links. Aviation talks have in fact already taken place, but Pakistan's demand for an Indian undertaking not to sever links again has created difficulties. Other proposals, for increased diplomatic representation, links between coast guards, and free medical care for 20 sick Pakistani children, seem less contentious.
"The hand of friendship" Mr Vajpayee extended to Pakistan in April has achieved few concrete results. India says cross-border infiltration in Kashmir continues; certainly the killing goes on. But the gesture proved very popular in India. With important state elections due in December, and a general election next year, Mr Vajpayee may want to milk that popularity for all its vote-pulling power. But effecting a transformation in India's relations with its neighbour has been a recurrent theme of his term in office. He is a statesman and wants to be remembered as such. But unless India agrees to talk about Kashmir, Pakistan will continue to treat Mr Vajpayee as just another Indian politician.
Caption: The hand of friendship

text:
In training for the big match next year
ELECTION fever is almost a permanent condition in India. But an imminent series of state elections is being followed with even more than usual interest across the country. Not only does it cover some big and important states. The results will also provide a pointer to the timing of the general election that has to be held by October next year, as well as to the plans and prospects of the competing parties. 
The first poll, on November 20th, is in the small north-eastern state of Mizoram. But it is the four that follow, on December 1st, that have national significance: in Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh and Delhi (not a full state, but the "national capital territory"). All are in India's Hindi-speaking heartland, where nearly half of the country's billion people live and where most general elections are decided. 
Moreover, all four states are held by the Congress party, which, at the national level, forms the main opposition to the ruling coalition led by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP); and in each case, unlike in many states where regional or caste-based parties are important forces, the battle is between Congress and the BJP. So these elections, in one sense, mirror next year's national poll. This is why the independent election commission upheld a complaint against a national advertising campaign by the BJP boasting of India's "shining" recent achievements.
The commission has had local difficulties to deal with, too. In Chhattisgarh, the state administration has proved chronically partisan, stooping even to the distribution of school bags decorated with pictures of the chief minister. Similarly, in Madhya Pradesh, the commission ruled against measures by the state government exempting large numbers of people from paying for electricity. 
Despite the perks of being in power, an abiding feature of Indian elections is the "anti-incumbency" factor. Almost every Indian government disappoints most voters, and suffers some electoral consequence. In these four states, however, the picture is more complicated. First, the "incumbency" burden is shared by Congress, locally, and the BJP at the national level. Second, it may this time be an advantage. An abundant monsoon, bringing relief and modest prosperity to drought-plagued areas, has lifted optimism about India's economic prospects higher than for several years. Government and private forecasters agree that the economy is likely to grow by 7% or more this fiscal year, ending next March.
Such complications may make it hard to judge which party, at the national level, has actually won these elections. The BJP's spokesman, Mukhtar Abbas Naqvi, stalwartly predicts a clear-cut victory for his party in all four. That, however, seems unlikely. In Delhi, opinion polls put Congress far ahead. One Congress leader claims that, fighting the incumbency handicap, three wins out of four would constitute an "extraordinary" success.
"The weak link in the chain", in his words, is Madhya Pradesh. There, the Congress chief minister, Digvijay Singh, has served two five-year terms already. The BJP candidate to replace him is Uma Bharti, a former government minister and a leading light in the campaign that culminated, 11 years ago, in the demolition of a mosque in the town of Ayodhya. That campaign, to build a temple to the Hindu god Ram on the site, was the BJP's springboard to national power. The 1992 riot also led last month to charges being filed against Miss Bharti for her involvement.
But in neither Madhya Pradesh nor elsewhere have Ayodhya and the other "cultural" issues that make up the BJP's Hindu-nationalist agenda played a big role in the election campaigns. Last month an attempt by groups linked to the BJP to revive the Ayodhya movement fizzled out. In Madhya Pradesh, it was Mr Singh who raised another "Hindu" demand for a national law banning the slaughter of cows, which Hindus regard as holy. "The desperate tactics of a loser", snorts Arun Jaitley, the government minister managing the BJP's campaign in the state. 
Victory in Madhya Pradesh would be a great encouragement for Mr Jaitley and Miss Bharti as the BJP prepares for a generational shift from the leadership of Atal Behari Vajpayee, the prime minister, and his deputy, L.K. Advani, both septuagenarians. In Congress, too, successful state chief ministers, such as Mr Singh or Rajasthan's Ashok Gehlot, may emerge as potential national leaders. In that sense, a clean sweep for Congress might not be entirely good news for its leader, the Italian-born Sonia Gandhi.
A BJP landslide, on the other hand--or at least victories in the big states of Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan--would increase pressure on Mr Vajpayee to call an early general election, and not risk having to face the consequences of a failed monsoon next summer. But Mahesh Rangarajan, one of the best-known political analysts in the country, thinks that is unlikely, for three reasons.
The BJP has still to work out what it wants to do in India's biggest state, Uttar Pradesh. Second, Mr Vajpayee wants his place in history as the first non-Congress prime minister to serve a full five-year term. Third, on November 14th, Chandrababu Naidu, the chief minister in another state, Andhra Pradesh, called for an early election, partly to pick up the sympathy vote after he narrowly escaped a terrorist assassination attempt last month. Mr Naidu's Telugu Desam Party is an important ally of the BJP in the central government. Its campaign for a state election that probably cannot be held before next March provides the cautious Mr Vajpayee with yet another reason to wait and see.

text:
Great news--but will the ceasefire hold?
THE guns fell silent on the long border between India and Pakistan at midnight on November 25th-26th, when the two nuclear powers marked the annual Muslim festival of Eid by beginning their first formal ceasefire for at least 20 years. Proposed on November 23rd by Zafarullah Jamali, Pakistan's prime minister, to apply to the line of control that divides the disputed territory of Kashmir, the ceasefire was extended at India's suggestion to cover the full border, including the remote Siachen Glacier in the Karakoram mountains, which has been a freezing battleground since 1984. 
Mr Jamali's initiative took India and most diplomatic observers by surprise. On October 22nd Atal Behari Vajpayee, India's prime minister, had received short shrift from Pakistan when he proposed 12 practical steps for improving relations. Yet just a month later, Mr Jamali was not only announcing a unilateral ceasefire, but also responded positively to several of Mr Vajpayee's October initiatives, including a cross-border bus service in Kashmir, a road route further south, and a restoration of rail and ferry links. 
Mr Jamali's change of heart has been described by some western diplomats as the most positive development for years in relations between two countries that have fought three wars since they became independent in 1947, two of them over Kashmir. The initiative probably stems from a variety of pressures, including international criticism of Pakistan's negative reaction to Mr Vajpayee's proposals. Pakistan has also faced mounting criticism from America, Britain and (more privately) China for providing refuge for al-Qaeda and Taliban activists, including terrorists who infiltrate across Pakistan's border into Indian Kashmir. 
Pakistan is anxious to ensure that Mr Vajpayee confirms his attendance at a regional South Asian conference in Islamabad early in January. It would however be difficult for Mr Vajpayee to attend the summit without holding bilateral talks--at least with Mr Jamali if not with General Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's president--and India has been insisting that there can be no such talks till Pakistan stops the cross-border infiltration. 
The immediate future of the current initiative--and the ceasefire--therefore primarily depends on the infiltration, which fortuitously always declines at this time of year, when mountain passes are closed by snow. The Indian government has made it clear that, while it has stopped routine shelling of Pakistan military posts, it will fire on any infiltrators that it spots crossing into Kashmir. That could lead to a resumption of hostilities and reduce the chances of the Vajpayee visit taking place. The visit may also depend on progress being made when the two hold talks, on December 1st, on resuming the aviation links currently blocked because of Pakistani reservations. 
India will now come under pressure to suspend its operations against militants in Indian Kashmir, which it last did alongside a temporary ceasefire almost three years ago. For the current initiatives to have much longer-term significance, and gradually develop into a peace process, it will also have to move ahead on talks with Kashmiri separatist groups who want some form of autonomy from Delhi, if not independence. 
On November 21st, the All-Party Hurriyat Conference, an umbrella organisation of moderate Kashmir separatist groups, agreed unconditionally to attend a first-ever formal meeting with L.K. Advani, India's deputy prime minister, that was offered alongside Mr Vajpayee's October 22nd initiative. This meeting is expected to take place early in December--but is already being criticised by a hardline breakaway Hurriyat faction that, significantly, Mr Jamali has recently recognised. The real proof of Pakistan's new interest in peace would be if it let the Hurriyat moderates make progress with the Indian government without fearing retribution from the hardliners. In the past, moderates have met with assassination. It must be different this time.
Caption: Jamali changes his tune

 On November 21st , the All - Party Hurriyat Conference , an umbrella organisation of moderate Kashmir separatist groups , agreed unconditionally to attend a first - ever formal meeting with L.K. Advani , India 's deputy prime minister , that was offered alongside Atal Bihari Vajpayee's October 22nd initiative . This meeting is expected to take place early in December -- but is already being criticised by a hardline breakaway Hurriyat faction that , significantly , Mr Jamali has recently recognised . The real proof of Pakistan 's new interest in peace would be if it let the Hurriyat moderates make progress with the Indian government without fearing retribution from the hardliners . In the past , moderates have met with assassination . It must be different this time .

text:
Encouragement for India's ruling party to call an early general election
LIKE his British counterpart, India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, has the power to dissolve parliament when he thinks his party might win an election. On December 4th, he might well have been thinking just that. The results of four important state elections held on December 1st were a big boost for his Hindu-nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), which leads India's governing coalition. But they were probably still not a convincing argument for bringing forward the national vote, which must be held by October next year. 
The elections were all in states held by the Congress party, which is the main national opposition. It kept only one: Delhi itself, where the local administration is thanked for having brought a tangible improvement in citizens' lives, through cleaner air, better transport and less sporadic electricity. 
Congress had already failed to win back another state, Mizoram, in the north-east, where elections were held on November 20th, from the former secessionists now in power. There, the swearing-in of the new assembly was delayed by violence on December 4th.
Local issues dominated all the campaigns. Except in a few areas, the BJP did not make much of "Hindu" issues, such as the campaign to build a temple to the god Ram in Ayodhya. The "anti-incumbency" factor that tends to handicap all ruling parties worked against Congress. In the biggest of the contests, in Madhya Pradesh, the BJP harped on basic infrastructure, still dismal after ten years of Congress rule, and won a landslide. In Rajasthan, where the state government is generally held to have coped well with a five-year drought that only ended with this summer's monsoon, the BJP also won comfortably, as in Chhattisgarh.
The BJP's best-ever performance in these three states in India's Hindi-speaking belt, where most general elections are decided, is a setback for Congress and its Italian-born leader, Sonia Gandhi. It will strengthen those voices in the BJP calling for early elections. National incumbency seems actually to have helped the party. Its spokesmen credit the current strength of India's economy, expected to grow by at least 7% this year. But the mood of national optimism is partly a consequence of the weather--an exceptionally good monsoon. So it could evaporate in a drought before next October.
Unlike Tony Blair, however, Mr Vajpayee cannot pick the date for an election. That is the job of a fiercely independent election commission, which has several months' leeway. That is one reason why Mr Vajpayee may be deterred from an early dissolution of parliament. Another is that he has unfinished business, both in organising his party for the electoral fray, and in securing his own legacy.
An enduring theme of his term in office has been a frustrating attempt to make peace with Pakistan. Twice before it has gone badly wrong, and last year even led to fears of all-out war between the two nuclear powers. His third peace effort is so far going better. This week it was announced that, after a two-year hiatus, the two countries will resume direct air links from January 1st. Further discussions on rail links are now to follow. Also in January, Mr Vajpayee will attend a regional summit in Islamabad, an opportunity for bilateral talks with Pakistan too. A lasting improvement in relations with Pakistan would ensure the patient Mr Vajpayee the place in history he seems to crave. It might also be a vote-winner.
