text:
A tale of corruption and murder
"IT SOUNDS like a movie plot," says Shekhar Gupta, editor of the Indian Express, a leading daily newspaper. An earnest young engineer reports poor construction work and corruption on a large-scale project to his bosses. Getting nowhere, he writes to the prime minister, who personally instigated the project but takes no notice. His letter leaks and the engineer is assassinated by the contractors' mafia to silence him and teach others a lesson. The government tries to ignore the issue but a campaigning newspaper takes up the cause. The middle class rise up, with 45,000 letters to the newspaper and signatures on an internet petition. This forces the prime minister to act, as government departments try to avoid blame by publicly attacking each other, and more stories emerge about honest officials being killed by the underworld.
Unfortunately, the plot is not fiction. It is being played out in India, where corruption on substandard construction projects is commonplace. Officials are frequently killed or kidnapped by gangs in Bihar, the country's most lawless state. On November 27th, Satyendra Dubey, a 31-year-old engineering graduate working as a project manager on a Bihar section of India's 5,850km (3,650 mile) Golden Quadrilateral highway project, was shot dead.
The $5.5 billion Quadrilateral project was launched in 1998 by Atal Behari Vajpayee, the prime minister, to improve India's ancient potholed road system with four- and six-lane highways linking major cities. Unusually for India, it is more or less on target for completion in a year's time, and officials say it is within budget--despite poor performance by some foreign companies, notably from China and Russia, and inexperienced local contractors.
The Indian Express obtained a copy of a letter that Mr Dubey had written a year earlier to Mr Vajpayee, providing details of the malpractice and asking for his identity to be kept secret. Mr Dubey's list of dodgy practices included international and other large contractors farming out most of their work on the cheap to inexperienced operators and labour gangs, project plans that were understated so that contractors could bill excessive extras, and companies' providing false evidence of their experience--all done, he said, with the co-operation of officials.
The letter was leaked by a government department to people involved on the contracts, and Mr Dubey received threats, which he reported to officials. They merely reprimanded him for writing. Now they are trying to deflect attention by pointing out that it is quite likely that Mr Dubey was killed by one of several contractors whom he had upset by, for example, forcing them to replace faulty work.
Either way, the saga exposes corruption in India's construction industry and the indifference of officials unused to justifying their actions publicly. The government now insists that procedures are being tightened, and Mr Vajpayee says that those responsible for Mr Dubey's death "will not be spared". But, as Mr Gupta puts it, the general government view seems to be that he was too honest for his own good.

text:
The news from Islamabad is hugely heartening. But the gains are hugely vulnerable
"HISTORY has been made," claimed Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's president, on January 6th, though "remade" would have been nearer the truth. At the summit meeting of a group of South Asian nations in Islamabad this week ()see page 49, General Musharraf and India's prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, clasped hands and put two dreadful years of sabre-rattling and terror behind them. The nuclear neighbours have now arrived, more or less, back where they were in 2001, before the failed Agra summit in July of that year and the attack on India's parliament building in Delhi that December drove them to the brink of Armageddon. The task now is to move beyond that point, and towards lasting peace.
It has been a difficult, gradual process, and one for which many actors deserve credit. Mr Vajpayee started things moving, in April last year, with a speech in which he held out "the hand of friendship" to Pakistan. That was pretty easy for him. Since India holds the best half of Kashmir, which lies at the heart of the two countries' differences, it can negotiate from a position of strength. Even so, it took a degree of political courage in the run-up to India's state and general elections. Pakistan-bashing, not handshakes, is what usually wins votes in India. General Musharraf deserves praise too, for eventually taking up that offer. Last week's announcement that he may no longer be insisting on a referendum in Kashmir, though arguably only a recognition of reality, helped a lot as well.
The Americans also deserve congratulation. Fearful of seeing a vital front in their war in terror disintegrate--as it would should India and Pakistan once again come to blows--they have twisted arms, the general's in particular, with vigour. For all that he is a key American ally, General Musharraf is also a big worry: an unstable, nuclear-armed (and proliferation-prone, )see page 50 Pakistan is a threat to the entire region, and potentially to America itself. But after the Americans talked tough last autumn, the general stepped up the pressure on extremist groups and sent his army into remote tribal areas to help with the work of flushing out the remnants of the Taliban and al-Qaeda there. In the past few weeks, he has finally persuaded the Indians that he is worth talking to again.
So now diplomatic links between Pakistan and India are fully restored, as are air links, with rail ones to return shortly and a bus service across the "line of control" in Kashmir in the offing. The Islamabad summiteers agreed that senior officials will start meeting in February, to discuss all areas of disagreement, Kashmir included. This is still far from the detailed framework for negotiation that the Agra summit was meant to establish, but it is a big step towards it. All the same, the main question remains just what it always has been: can goodwill and talks be turned into a durable peace?
Always Kashmir
It certainly won't be easy. Pakistan and India have been arguing over Kashmir for close to half a century. Two of the three wars the neighbours have fought have been over this scrap of territory. India now holds about half of what was once a princely state, where a Hindu maharajah held sway over his mainly Muslim subjects, and Pakistan most of the rest, though China has nabbed a little too. Kashmir (India's part of it) is not just extraordinarily beautiful, but of strategic importance. India fears that a Pakistani Kashmir, or an independent one that looked towards its fellow Muslim country, would be an impregnable redoubt menacing its rich northern states. More generally, India fears the principle of self-determination. If it were granted to Kashmir, it might reasonably be demanded right across India's multi-ethnic patchwork.
For Pakistan, though, the stakes are hardly any smaller. The quest to liberate the fellow Muslims of Kashmir started with independence in 1947. So many lives have been shed in pursuit of this aim that surrender would be deeply painful. India would be delighted to turn the existing division, which gives it the heart of the state, into a permanent border. But for Pakistan, this would be a humiliating defeat. The very name Pakistan, a modern invention, includes a "K" for Kashmir.
Might it not be possible for talks on the issue to drag ponderously on while other aspects of the relationship between these two powerful countries become a little more normal? At present there is virtually no trade across the long India-Pakistan border--though the hope, expressed at the Islamabad meeting, is that this could now start to change, with a South Asian free-trade zone planned for as early as 2006.
In some parts of the world, it has seemed possible to spin a peace process out forever without encountering a bloody breakdown. Cyprus certainly qualifies, with no hostilities to speak of for a quarter-century--but no resolution either. Northern Ireland looks as though it is sliding into the same category. But talks that drag on for years and years also carry their risks. Palestine provides one counter-example: on both sides are zealots who make compromise all but impossible, and who are prepared to resort to violence to pre-empt any risk of it. Sadly, there is reason to think that Kashmir may fall into this category. The lesson of the past two years or so is that relations between India and Pakistan are extraordinarily sensitive to the actions of violent men.
There are two great dangers. One is that Islamic terrorists, nurtured by Pakistan's intelligence service for the long proxy war with India in Kashmir, will refuse to accept that they have outlived their usefulness. It would take only one large bomb directed against a civilian target in the Indian heartland for all the good work of Mr Vajpayee and General Musharraf to be undone. The other danger is even more chilling. By abandoning the Taliban and siding with America in Afghanistan, by taking on militancy at home, and now by moderating his demands on Kashmir, the general has become the prime target of the terrorist groups that infect his country. Two bomb attempts in December revealed a degree of inside knowledge of the general's movements, and only narrowly missed. Stanley Baldwin warned in the 1930s that "the bomber will always get through". Should that happen in Pakistan, the dream of peace with India could well be among the casualties.

text:
Pakistan's Pervez Musharraf and India's Atal Behari Vajpayee have turned away from confrontation. Now they must pick their next step
THE leaders of India and Pakistan may both have benefited from their joint announcement on January 6th, at a regional conference in Islamabad, that they are to start talking about issues that have divided the two countries for decades. Atal Behari Vajpayee, India's prime minister, has enhanced his reputation as a peacemaker and international statesman. This appears to have bolstered the already strong position of his Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) as it prepares for the general election now expected in India in April. General Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's president, has shown that, in spite of two assassination attempts in the past four weeks, he is starting to address worries at home and abroad about his country being a base for terrorism. He can also now claim, though many are still sceptical, that he is genuine about making peace with India. 
The agreement to hold a "composite dialogue"--which is to start next month--goes further than anyone had expected. The joint statement said General Musharraf had reassured Mr Vajpayee that "he will not permit any territory under Pakistan's control to be used to support terrorism in any manner." Talks between the two leaders in Agra in July 2001 foundered on Pakistan's refusal to offer precisely that assurance. In exchange, Mr Vajpayee agreed to say that "the two leaders are confident that the resumption of the composite dialogue will lead to a peaceful settlement of all bilateral issues, including Jammu & Kashmir, to the satisfaction of both sides." This implies a recognition by India of Pakistan's interest in any solution to the problem of divided Kashmir, a far cry from its past position that Kashmir was an integral part of India, and that Pakistan should have no say in its resolution.
So far, so good. But the road to peace on the subcontinent has seen many such hopes collapse in anguish. 
In 1989, as young prime ministers, Pakistan's Benazir Bhutto and India's Rajiv Gandhi tried to make peace but failed, and the two countries came to the brink of war in 1990. In 1997, Pakistan's Nawaz Sharif and India's Inder Kumar Gujral agreed to a process of dialogue, but relations soured after the BJP came to power in India in 1998 and both countries tested nuclear weapons. In 1999, Mr Sharif and Mr Vajpayee agreed in Lahore to bury the hatchet, but some months later Pakistan--whose army chief at the time was General Musharraf--launched an assault on India in the Kashmir region of Kargil. In 2001, Mr Musharraf and Mr Vajpayee held a doomed summit in Agra, and relations grew much worse the following December when Pakistani-sponsored militants launched a suicide attack on the Indian parliament in Delhi. That attack provoked another near-war, which some feared could have turned nuclear. This strengthened America's determination to push the two countries into a long-term rapprochement.
The new thrust started last April when Mr Vajpayee announced his readiness to normalise relations with Pakistan on the basis of "trust and sincerity". General Musharraf responded by saying he was ready for unconditional talks, but India refused while terrorist attacks continued in Kashmir. In November, India offered confidence-building measures, including the restoration of stalled air, rail and sea links, as well as sporting and full diplomatic ties, which Pakistan, after some hesitation, eventually accepted. 
Both sides then began to make conciliatory statements in advance of a seven-country conference of the South Asian Association for Regional Co-operation (SAARC), which provided the occasion for the talks and itself launched anti-terrorism and regional trade initiatives. General Musharraf announced "unprecedented flexibility" in Pakistan's historical attitude toward Kashmir by saying that the United Nations resolutions calling for a plebiscite on its future "could be set aside in the interests of a realistic compromise". India approvingly noted that Pakistan's "mindset seemed to have changed" and acknowledged that fewer militants were entering Kashmir from Pakistan.
The leaders of the two countries now have to decide how to take the Islamabad agreement forward and thwart the efforts of the extremists on both sides who, General Musharraf admitted, would try to derail the peace process. The general is acting from a position of relative strength, despite the two recent assassination attempts. In the past few weeks, he has brokered a deal with Pakistan's parliamentary opposition to amend the constitution and legitimise his seizure of power in 1999. He has also obtained a vote of confidence from parliament, making him, at last, a legitimate president for five years. 
Mr Vajpayee's BJP is expected to decide at an executive-council meeting on January 11th to call for India's general election, due to be held by September, to be brought forward. Mr Vajpayee will want to keep the Islamabad momentum going in the approach to the polls, but without doing anything that might be criticised by anti-Muslim hardliners in his Hindu-nationalist party. He also has to decide how to balance internal reforms in Kashmir alongside talks with Pakistan. 
In the past, Kashmiris have called either for independence or for a takeover by Pakistan. Extremists still make these demands. But most people in the disputed territory now call, more modestly, for Delhi to give the state of Jammu & Kashmir a high degree of autonomy within India.
Though the Indian government has paid lip-service to this idea, it has made no progress. It is happy enough with the status quo, and has seen little point in making concessions in advance of any negotiations with Pakistan. Nor has it had an obvious interlocutor in Kashmir. The state's present government is regarded as representative neither by the extremists nor by activists in the All-Party Hurriyat Conference, an umbrella organisation of Kashmiri separatist groups. Moderate leaders of the Hurriyat are due to meet L.K. Advani, India's deputy prime minister, soon. But they dare not do so without a nod from Pakistan: two of their leading moderates have been murdered in the past 18 months. Perhaps General Musharraf's next move should be to back this Hurriyat meeting, which could open the way to talks involving more of the interested parties.

In exchange , Mr Vajpayee agreed to say that " Atal Bihari Vajpayee are confident that the resumption of the composite dialogue will lead to a peaceful settlement of all bilateral issues , including Jammu & Kashmir , to the satisfaction of both sides . " This implies a recognition by India of Pakistan 's interest in any solution to the problem of divided Kashmir , a far cry from its past position that Kashmir was an integral part of India , and that Pakistan should have no say in its resolution . 
 So far , so good . But the road to peace on the subcontinent has seen many such hopes collapse in anguish . 
 In 1989 , as young prime ministers , Pakistan 's Benazir Bhutto and India 's Rajiv Gandhi tried to make peace but failed , and the two countries came to the brink of war in 1990 . In 1997 , Pakistan 's Nawaz Sharif and India 's Inder Kumar Gujral agreed to a process of dialogue , but relations soured after the BJP came to power in India in 1998 and both countries tested nuclear weapons . In 1999 , Atal Bihari Vajpayee agreed in Lahore to bury the hatchet , but some months later Pakistan -- whose army chief at the time was General Musharraf -- launched an assault on India in the Kashmir region of Kargil . In 2001 , Atal Bihari Vajpayee held a doomed summit in Agra , and relations grew much worse the following December when Pakistani - sponsored militants launched a suicide attack on the Indian parliament in Delhi . That attack provoked another near - war , which some feared could have turned nuclear . This strengthened America 's determination to push the two countries into a long - term rapprochement . 
 The new thrust started last April when Mr Vajpayee announced his readiness to normalise relations with Pakistan on the basis of " trust and sincerity " . General Musharraf responded by saying he was ready for unconditional talks , but India refused while terrorist attacks continued in Kashmir . In November , India offered confidence - building measures , including the restoration of stalled air , rail and sea links , as well as sporting and full diplomatic ties , which Pakistan , after some hesitation , eventually accepted . 
 Both sides then began to make conciliatory statements in advance of a seven - country conference of the South Asian Association for Regional Co - operation ( SAARC ) , which provided the occasion for the talks and itself launched anti - terrorism and regional trade initiatives . General Musharraf announced " unprecedented flexibility " in Pakistan 's historical attitude toward Kashmir by saying that the United Nations resolutions calling for a plebiscite on its future " could be set aside in the interests of a realistic compromise " . India approvingly noted that Pakistan 's " mindset seemed to have changed " and acknowledged that fewer militants were entering Kashmir from Pakistan . 
 Atal Bihari Vajpayee now have to decide how to take the Islamabad agreement forward and thwart the efforts of the extremists on both sides who , General Musharraf admitted , would try to derail the peace process . The general is acting from a position of relative strength , despite the two recent assassination attempts . In the past few weeks , he has brokered a deal with Pakistan 's parliamentary opposition to amend the constitution and legitimise his seizure of power in 1999 . He has also obtained a vote of confidence from parliament , making him , at last , a legitimate president for five years . 
 Mr Vajpayee 's BJP is expected to decide at an executive - council meeting on January 11th to call for India 's general election , due to be held by September , to be brought forward . Mr Vajpayee will want to keep the Islamabad momentum going in the approach to the polls , but without doing anything that might be criticised by anti - Muslim hardliners in his Hindu - nationalist party . He also has to decide how to balance internal reforms in Kashmir alongside talks with Pakistan . 
 In the past , Kashmiris have called either for independence or for a takeover by Pakistan . Extremists still make these demands . But most people in the disputed territory now call , more modestly , for Delhi to give the state of Jammu & Kashmir a high degree of autonomy within India . 
 Though the Indian government has paid lip - service to this idea , it has made no progress . It is happy enough with the status quo , and has seen little point in making concessions in advance of any negotiations with Pakistan . Nor has it had an obvious interlocutor in Kashmir . The state 's present government is regarded as representative neither by the extremists nor by activists in the All - Party Hurriyat Conference , an umbrella organisation of Kashmiri separatist groups . Moderate leaders of the Hurriyat are due to meet L.K. Advani , India 's deputy prime minister , soon . But they dare not do so without a nod from Pakistan : two of their leading moderates have been murdered in the past 18 months . Perhaps General Musharraf 's next move should be to back this Hurriyat meeting , which could open the way to talks involving more of the interested parties .

text:
Politics
The American-led administration in Iraq was in a bind after the country's most influential Shia Muslim cleric, Ayatollah Ali Sistani, again insisted on direct elections to an interim parliament that is supposed, under the Americans' current plan, to choose a full-fledged Iraqi government by July. The Americans still want the parliament to be chosen by caucuses of notables. Tens of thousands of protesters took to the streets of Basra demanding direct elections.
Though the United Nations says it has no plan to send back staff who were withdrawn from Iraq after the UN's headquarters in Baghdad were blown up in August, a UN team will visit the city in the next fortnight to look at security and transport arrangements in case the organisation does decide to return.
Deputies staged a sit-in in parliament after Iran's highest body, the conservative Guardian Council, where the country's ayatollahs hold sway, disqualified about half the 8,200 people hoping to stand in next month's parliamentary election. Those banned included 80 incumbent MPs.
Friends of Ariel Sharon, Israel's prime minister, continued to fend off charges of improper election-campaign funding after a tape of a business transaction involving him--but so far deemed legal by the official election-monitoring body--was aired on Israeli television.
A Palestinian suicide bomber killed herself and four Israelis at a Gaza crossing-point to Israel. In a break with usual practice, the Palestinian prime minister, Ahmed Qurei, declined to condemn the attack.
Poor Swaziland's King Mswati ordered nine new palaces to be built to house seven current and two future wives at a cost of pounds 8m ($14.5m). 
The road to Iowa
The Democratic presidential contenders held their last debate before the Iowa caucuses. A new poll showed that Howard Dean and Wesley Clark (who is skipping the Iowa event) are the clear favourites among Democratic voters nationwide.
Paul O'Neill, George Bush's first treasury secretary, alleged that the administration began preparations to invade Iraq soon after taking office in January 2001. He also claimed that Mr Bush was like "a blind man in a room full of deaf people" when it came to decision making. The Treasury has asked for an investigation into Mr O'Neill's possible misuse of classified documents.
The Supreme Court said it would not hear a case on secrecy procedures used by the Justice Department when it detained and then deported over 700 foreigners, mostly Arabs and Muslims, in the aftermath of the September 11th attacks. An appeals court has already agreed with the administration that releasing the names of the individuals could compromise intelligence-gathering operations.
Mr Bush unveiled ambitious plans to build a lunar base and then to put a man on Mars.
Arnold Schwarzenegger unveiled his first budget as California's governor. The $99 billion plan proposes cuts in spending on education, health and welfare programmes, but no tax increases. He said that if his bond proposal did not succeed in a ballot in March, the state would face a $14 billion deficit.
At the summit
Heads of state from north, south and central America met at a "special" Summit of the Americas in Monterrey, Mexico. There were arguments over trade, among other things. George Bush's new immigration scheme met with some approval, but a dispute between Brazil and the Unites States over immigration checks continued. In retaliation for American measures partly designed to detect terrorists, Americans entering Brazil are being photographed and fingerprinted.
In a surprising reversal of policy, Mr Bush announced that Canadian companies would be eligible to bid for future reconstruction contracts in Iraq. France and other critics of the Iraq war are still shut out of the bidding.
Demonstrations designed to oust President Jean-Bertrand Aristide of Haiti continued. Mr Aristide says he is willing to hold fresh elections.
Happy new year?
Sri Lanka's president, Chandrika Kumaratunga, caused a row when she claimed she was entitled to an extra year in office. She was inaugurated for her second six-year term, in 1999, a year earlier than she needed to be, she says.
The prime minister of India, Atal Behari Vajpayee, said he hoped elections would be called in April, six months early. A train from Pakistan crossed into India for the first time in two years, marking a further thaw in relations between the two countries.
South Korea's foreign minister "resigned" for not reflecting official policy. Not critical enough of America, said the rumours.
Losing immunity
Italy's constitutional court dealt another blow to Silvio Berlusconi. It ruled that a law passed last June giving the Italian prime minister and four other top officials immunity from prosecution was unconstitutional. A trial of Mr Berlusconi on judge-bribing charges, which was suspended last July, is now likely to resume.
The European Commission is to take European governments to the European Court of Justice for breaking the stability and growth pact, which sets ceilings on euro-area countries' budget deficits. Last November, the governments overruled a commission recommendation that France and Germany should trim their deficits this year, and sought to put the pact in abeyance. 
After pressure from Turkey, a coalition government was formed in northern Cyprus that will seek to reopen unification talks with the Greek-Cypriot south. Turkey is anxious to begin negotiations on accession to the European Union: but the EU has made clear that, if Cyprus is still divided when it joins in May, the Turks will have little chance.
Germany's armed forces are to be shaken up. The army will be cut in size and made more professional, but the defence minister, Peter Struck, said that conscription will remain. There was no hint of more defence spending: Germany spends less on defence as a proportion of GDP than other big NATO countries.

text:
The prime minister's stock is soaring
IN THE middle of 2002 Atal Behari Vajpayee, India's prime minister, looked as though he might hobble off the world stage on ailing knees, taking his creaking body into political retirement. Time magazine ran a big story on how this "ordinary old man" was spending "the twilight of his political life where he wants to be--out to lunch". Nearly two years later, Mr Vajpayee still walks hesitantly on reconstructed knees, often speaks disconcertingly slowly, and enjoys his lunch more than he perhaps should at 79. But he is increasingly recognised as one of the world's most surprising statesmen. Now he is pushing his Bharatiya Janata Party's (BJP) multi-party coalition into an early general election, confident of a victory that few analysts are yet prepared to question. 
In the past fortnight Mr Vajpayee has pulled off a reconciliation with President Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, setting the two countries on the most promising, if uncertain, path to peace for years. He persuaded President George Bush to announce, on January 12th, a long-awaited co-operation agreement in high technology, space and nuclear products, which will beef up India-American relations. He got Jaswant Singh, his finance minister, to produce not one but two generous pre-election mini-budgets on January 8th and 9th. And L.K. Advani, his deputy prime minister, is to back up planned talks between India and Pakistan by meeting leaders from Kashmir's separatist All-Party Hurriyat Conference on January 22nd for their first-ever formal talks on devolution.
Mr Vajpayee also seems energised by the prospect of the election campaign. At a recent political rally he spoke with the sort of force and clarity that once made him famous as an orator, and said he hoped a new government would be in place by the end of April. 
The prime minister's 2002 low point came when more than 2,000 people were killed in Hindu-Muslim riots in Gujarat. Afterwards, the state's controversial chief minister, Narendra Modi, won a landslide assembly victory for the BJP on an anti-Muslim ticket. That strengthened hardliners within the Sangh Parivar, the Hindu "family of organisations" to which the BJP belongs, and led to fears of similarly provocative election campaigning elsewhere. But, following a defeat in a small northern state, Mr Vajpayee tacked to a more moderate line, with campaigns stressing development and stable government. He was rewarded in December with election victories in three key states. 
Mr Vajpayee now seems unlikely to retire before his health compels him to, and certainly not, as was mooted a year or so ago, soon after the coming election. "If he works at 79, he can work at 84," says Pramod Mahajan, a prominent BJP politician. That seems to be accepted by the 76-year-old Mr Advani, who has long been a rival as well as an ally, and whose prospects of becoming prime minister fade the longer Mr Vajpayee remains. Mr Advani is seen as a nationalist hardliner. He cannot mount a challenge now because he knows that he would find it difficult to hold the BJP's National Democratic Alliance coalition together, let alone win an election, if Mr Vajpayee were to depart.
The BJP's election confidence stems partly from disarray in Congress, the main opposition party, which is ineptly led by the Italian-born Sonia Gandhi, widow of Rajiv Gandhi, the former prime minister assassinated in 1991. The BJP plans to campaign on a strong economy (with growth of over 7% last year), stable government and now the prospect of peace with Pakistan. It adds up to a hard act to beat.
Caption: Vajpayee triumphant

text:
Can Sonia Gandhi lead Congress to victory?
IT IS all a question of branding. Is Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born president of Congress, India's main opposition party, marketable as the heiress of the Nehru-Gandhi dynasty, or will her foreign origins turn off India's 650m voters? India's forthcoming general election, now expected in April, will see Mrs Gandhi, an inexperienced politician, competing against Atal Behari Vajpayee, the politically savvy prime minister. His Bharatiya Janata Party certainly intends to make Mrs Gandhi's origins an issue in the election.
Mrs Gandhi is a reluctant recruit to politics, as was her husband Rajiv, assassinated in 1991. But Rajiv Gandhi was the grandson of Jawaharlal Nehru, India's first prime minister, and the son of Indira Gandhi, the prime minister murdered in 1984. He had no difficulty leading Congress to victory after his mother's death. Whether his widow can turn the thousands who come to see her into votes is still uncertain. 
Since she became politically active as Congress president in 1998, Sonia Gandhi has failed to emerge as an effective leader. She has been shielded from public exposure by a coterie of advisers and sycophantic hangers-on. Believing that she might not survive politically in the public glare, party officials hoped that Congress would inherit power by default when Mr Vajpayee's coalition collapsed. But the coalition has not collapsed, and Congress fared poorly in recent local elections.
There has been "ineffectual communication of what she stands for, so she has been robbed of any equity brand or identity," says Suhel Seth of Equus, a Delhi-based branding company, who advises politicians. More simply, "She is seen as an Italian pretending to be an Indian politician." It is not even clear whether she expects to become prime minister. Her official line is that this will be decided after the polls. The party's politicians, however, insist they expect her to have the job if Congress wins over 180 seats in parliament--it took 112 out of 545 in the last election, in 1999--and secures enough coalition allies. 
Politicians close to Mrs Gandhi say she has little-known virtues. Kapil Sibal, a Congress spokesman, says she would be "a more honest, secular and forthright prime minister than Vajpayee." Ashwani Kumar, a lawyer who runs a party think-tank, says that family members "are relevant because they are the symbol of sacrifice and continuity in the history of Congress and modern India." But his argument is unlikely to mean much to India's emerging young middle class.
The line does not end with Mrs Gandhi. Her son and daughter, Rahul and Priyanka, so far not active in politics, have just visited two family-linked constituencies in Uttar Pradesh. Priyanka Gandhi is expected to become a parliamentary candidate there, and her brother may also stand, perhaps in Tamil Nadu in the south. The party believes this would help, especially if Mrs Gandhi becomes more approachable. She has embarked on a rural tour and broken with tradition by visiting potential allies to ask them to join a coalition, instead of waiting for supplicants. But time is short for image-transformation--especially when the marketability of the basic brand is in doubt.
Caption: Trying to carry the flame

text:
At last, what looks like a process
AFTER nearly 60 years of bitter dispute between India and Pakistan over the sovereignty of Kashmir, and 14 years of bloody insurgency in the Indian-administered part of the territory, no one expects a swift resolution. But at least, says Amitabh Mattoo, an Indian expert on the region, "for the first time in years you can see light at the end of the tunnel." Two sets of talks--between India and Pakistan, and between the Indian government and moderate Kashmiri separatists--offer negotiation a chance, however slim, of succeeding where violence has failed.
This week India and Pakistan set dates, February 16th-18th, for a first round of promised talks between senior diplomats on all bilateral issues, including Kashmir. Indian officials, meanwhile, were congratulating themselves that a ground-breaking meeting on January 22nd between L.K. Advani, the deputy prime minister, and a group of Kashmiri separatist leaders, had gone better than most had expected. The five-member delegation from the All-Party Hurriyat Conference was rewarded with an audience with the prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee. The delegation, according to Umar Farooq, one of its members, found him "serious and sincere about finding the way out." 
Little concrete came out of the discussion. The two sides agreed to meet again, in late March; to pursue a "step-by-step approach" through dialogue; and India promised to "examine" the cases of the hundreds of people detained in Kashmir as suspected militants. But after talking only indirectly or clandestinely, if at all, for so long, this represents progress, even if the shape of an acceptable final compromise remains hard to discern. It looks like the start of something that has not existed until now: a peace process.
But will that process endure? The danger is that the dialogue itself could disqualify the Kashmiri participants as representatives of those struggling for freedom from India. Mr Farooq, the mirwaiz, a hereditary post making him the Kashmir valley's senior Muslim cleric, and the other members of the delegation do have a popular following. But as Mr Mattoo, who is vice-chancellor of the University of Jammu in Indian Kashmir, puts it, "these are not towering leaders who can carry the population with them."
They will need to show that the talks are yielding real benefits--such as the release of detainees and a less intrusive and abusive Indian security presence--if they are not to be seen as selling out. Mr Farooq hopes that India is poised to announce a ceasefire towards militants, though Mr Advani has played down that possibility. Mr Farooq would also like India to let the Hurriyat travel to Pakistan to meet leaders there, thereby completing the third side of a "triangular" dialogue, and visit the militants running camps in Pakistan-administered Kashmir in order to appeal for a reciprocal truce.
A complete end to violence seems a very ambitious hope. More pressing is the need to protect the limited progress made already from the many onslaughts it could face: the tirades of those pro-Pakistan and pro-independence Kashmiris who have denounced the dialogue; terrorist attacks designed to provoke a violent Indian response and thwart any softening of its army's behaviour; perhaps even the assassination of moderate Hurriyat leaders, which was the sad fate of the father of Bilal Lone, one member of the Kashmiri delegation, in 2002. The previous mirwaiz, too, was murdered in 1990, which may have helped shape his son's view that "there is no other way" than dialogue.

At last , what looks like a process 
 AFTER nearly 60 years of bitter dispute between India and Pakistan over the sovereignty of Kashmir , and 14 years of bloody insurgency in the Indian - administered part of the territory , no one expects a swift resolution . But at least , says Amitabh Mattoo , an Indian expert on the region , " for the first time in years you can see light at the end of the tunnel . " Two sets of talks -- between India and Pakistan , and between the Indian government and moderate Kashmiri separatists -- offer negotiation a chance , however slim , of succeeding where violence has failed . 
 This week India and Pakistan set dates , February 16th-18th , for a first round of promised talks between senior diplomats on all bilateral issues , including Kashmir . Indian officials , meanwhile , were congratulating themselves that a ground - breaking meeting on January 22nd between L.K. Advani , the deputy prime minister , and a group of Kashmiri separatist leaders , had gone better than most had expected . The five - member delegation from the All - Party Hurriyat Conference was rewarded with an audience with Atal Bihari Vajpayee . The delegation , according to Umar Farooq , one of its members , found Atal Bihari Vajpayee " serious and sincere about finding the way out . " 
 Little concrete came out of the discussion . The two sides agreed to meet again , in late March ; to pursue a " step - by - step approach " through dialogue ; and India promised to " examine " the cases of the hundreds of people detained in Kashmir as suspected militants . But after talking only indirectly or clandestinely , if at all , for so long , this represents progress , even if the shape of an acceptable final compromise remains hard to discern . It looks like the start of something that has not existed until now : a peace process . 
 But will that process endure ? The danger is that the dialogue itself could disqualify the Kashmiri participants as representatives of those struggling for freedom from India . Mr Farooq , the mirwaiz , a hereditary post making him the Kashmir valley 's senior Muslim cleric , and the other members of the delegation do have a popular following . But as Mr Mattoo , who is vice - chancellor of the University of Jammu in Indian Kashmir , puts it , " these are not towering leaders who can carry the population with them . " 
 They will need to show that the talks are yielding real benefits -- such as the release of detainees and a less intrusive and abusive Indian security presence -- if they are not to be seen as selling out . Mr Farooq hopes that India is poised to announce a ceasefire towards militants , though Mr Advani has played down that possibility . Mr Farooq would also like India to let the Hurriyat travel to Pakistan to meet leaders there , thereby completing the third side of a " triangular " dialogue , and visit the militants running camps in Pakistan - administered Kashmir in order to appeal for a reciprocal truce . 
 A complete end to violence seems a very ambitious hope . More pressing is the need to protect the limited progress made already from the many onslaughts it could face : the tirades of those pro - Pakistan and pro - independence Kashmiris who have denounced the dialogue ; terrorist attacks designed to provoke a violent Indian response and thwart any softening of its army 's behaviour ; perhaps even the assassination of moderate Hurriyat leaders , which was the sad fate of the father of Bilal Lone , one member of the Kashmiri delegation , in 2002 . The previous mirwaiz , too , was murdered in 1990 , which may have helped shape his son 's view that " there is no other way " than dialogue .

text:
As India and Pakistan begin talks on improving relations, the people of disputed Kashmir are torn between hope, anger and despair
IN THE middle of Srinagar, the main city of the Kashmir Valley, the streets still bustle. The placid waters of the Dal Lake, the city's glory, are plied by lonely tourist-hunting boatmen under a winter sun glinting off snow-streaked mountain peaks. But the shoreline is patrolled by rifle-toting Indian soldiers. Armoured vehicles police the markets, and moderate separatist leaders go surrounded by security guards for fear of assassination. 
"Militancy", the local euphemism for explosions and other acts of terrorism, persists, as does Indian counter-insurgency. In recent weeks, India's forces have managed to kill several prominent militant leaders. On February 6th, in a traditionally pro-Pakistan area of Srinagar, a demand that police release the body of one leader, Rafiq Dar, turned into a near-riot. A mob pelted the cars of separatist leaders with stones, in protest at their ineffectiveness in resisting India. Three days later, 15,000 people demonstrated against the killing of five civilians in an army operation. 
Among the resisters, who have been struggling bloodily for 15 years, the mood is bitter. "Everybody knows India has won," says one. "It has used violence to tire people out. Now, there will be no dignified way out." Others may be less candid, but many share the anger and humiliation. 
Yet this is supposed to be a moment of unprecedented hope in Kashmir's long agony. At a meeting in Islamabad last month, Atal Behari Vajpayee, India's prime minister, and Pervez Musharraf, Pakistan's president and army chief, edged away from long-entrenched positions. India accepted that Kashmir was a "bilateral issue" that could be discussed with Pakistan, and needed settlement. For his part, General Musharraf promised to lend no support to terrorism. This was taken as a pledge to stop financing, training and arming the militant infiltrators India blames for fomenting and waging the uprising in Kashmir. Next week, from February 16th-18th, senior diplomats from the two countries will meet, again in Islamabad, to start mapping out plans for a "composite dialogue" that will include Kashmir.
Last month saw another hint of a thaw. Mr Vajpayee's deputy, Lal Krishna Advani, held talks in Delhi with a group representing factions of the All-Party Hurriyat Conference, an umbrella for various Kashmiri separatist groups. The delegation visited Mr Vajpayee, too, and declared him serious about achieving peace. 
That so many in Kashmir discount the prospects for peace stems, in part, from the fact that Kashmiris will take no part in next week's talks. But they also say they have seen no improvement in their daily lives. This is not entirely fair. Along the "line of control" that divides Indian- from Pakistani-administered Kashmir, a ceasefire declared by Pakistan last November and reciprocated by India has ended the ritual cross-border shooting and shelling. In Srinagar, these days, soldiers spend more time in their bunkers and less frisking passers-by.
A "healing touch" was the promise held out to Kashmiris by the new state government that took power after the elections of November 2002. The ballot had been boycotted, as usual, by the Hurriyat, and few people in the Valley voted, but it was generally seen as free and fair. The winning coalition, led by the People's Democratic Party (PDP), freed some detainees, including a few leading separatists, and a much-hated Special Operations Group (SOG) of the Indian police was merged with regular forces.
But Pervez Imroz, a human-rights lawyer in Srinagar, sees no difference between the present government and its predecessors in their inability to hold the security forces to account. Harassment of civilians continues in the countryside. The SOG may have been disbanded in name, but it continues to operate. Many Kashmiris believe that killings in "encounters" with the army or police, such as that of Mr Dar, are in fact deaths after torture in custody. 
Disappearances continue, and are blamed on the security forces. The state government suggests that 3,931 people have disappeared since the uprising began. The police deny this, claiming that most of those who have vanished fled of their own accord, some to join militant groups. Mr Imroz believes the true number of the disappeared is around 8,000. Militants, too, abuse human rights, and in some places are more feared than the Indian army. They have a grisly record of mistreating civilians and of killing their own comrades when they show signs of moderation. 
Kashmiris are weary of war, but scepticism about recent "breakthroughs" is understandable. It has deep roots in history, in the divisions among Kashmiris themselves, and in the strong arguments against every "solution" proposed so far. 
The wavering maharajah
Almost every interview with a Kashmiri politician starts with a history lesson, dating from the partition of India in 1947. India's "princely states", which had retained notional independence, were given the option of acceding to India or to Pakistan. One such was Jammu & Kashmir, which had a Muslim majority but a Hindu maharajah. He vacillated, until his hand was forced by a tribal rebellion in part of his kingdom, backed by Pakistani tribesmen and regular soldiers. To secure military help, he acceded to India in October 1947, and the first of three India-Pakistan wars started. India appealed to the United Nations Security Council, which in January 1948 passed the first of its 18 resolutions on Kashmir.
Later that year, the UN called for a plebiscite to ask Kashmiris to choose between India and Pakistan, once Pakistan's forces had withdrawn. Pakistan still demands that the vote be held. But the first war ended in July 1949 with Kashmir divided, as it still is. India, viewing Pakistan as illegally occupying part of its territory, argues that a plebiscite is irrelevant.
The war left India in control of about 45% of the old kingdom's land area. The Indian state of Jammu & Kashmir now incorporates three parts: Ladakh, divided between Buddhists and Muslims; Jammu, with a Hindu majority; and the 130km (80 mile) -long, 55km-wide Kashmir Valley, which has a Muslim majority and more than half the state's population of 10m. Some 3m Kashmiris live under Pakistani rule in "Azad" ("free") Kashmir and the Northern Areas. To complicate things further, some 20% of largely uninhabited historic Kashmir is under Chinese control. 
Under "temporary provisions" enshrined in Article 370 of India's constitution, the state of Jammu & Kashmir was promised considerable autonomy. But this has never materialised. After an egregiously rigged state election in 1987, some Kashmiris took up arms. Some of their compatriots from Pakistan-controlled Kashmir began to join their struggle. So too, through the 1990s, did increasing numbers of Pakistanis, Afghans, Chechens and others, seeing in Kashmir a jihad like that in the 1980s against the Soviet occupation of Afghanistan. 
Pakistan's army and intelligence services have helped run the war. The firing over the line of control was seen by India as a device to provide cover for infiltrators. In the winter months, when the high mountain passes into the Kashmir Valley are snowbound, infiltration tails off anyway. This year, says India, it has halted almost altogether. India is waiting to see if the summer brings an expected rise in "exfiltration", in implicit fulfilment of General Musharraf's promise.
By Indian estimates, some 40,000 people have died in the war. Leading members of the Hurriyat say 100,000. Even last year, when relations were improving, more than 3,000 people were killed. The Indian army says they included 818 civilians and 1,345 "terrorists", 935 of them foreigners. Some 500,000 Indian soldiers, paramilitaries and police are stationed in the territory, fighting an estimated 2,000-3,000 militants. At times the conflict threatens to widen. In 1999, Pakistani incursions in the Kargil area, planned by General Musharraf before he seized power in a coup, led to fighting in which at least 1,000 soldiers died. In 2002, after India blamed Pakistan-backed terrorists for attacks the year before on the assembly in Srinagar and the parliament in Delhi, hundreds of thousands of troops massed on the line of control and the international border. Full-scale--even nuclear--war seemed possible.
As Pakistan sees it
Some proposals for stopping the slaughter date back half a century. Pakistan still demands a plebiscite. It has two fundamental reasons for clinging to its claim. It was founded as the homeland for India's Muslims, and feels incomplete without its neighbouring Muslim-majority state. Kashmir was the "K" in the acronym that made up the name Pakistan, which also means "land of the pure". Without Kashmir, "Pakistan" is literally meaningless. Second, Pakistan's army has long hankered after the "strategic depth" Kashmir would give it. It will never feel utterly safe without it. There is a third reason for fuelling the war, however: at a low cost to Pakistan, it keeps half of India's army tied up.
Syed Ali Shah Geelani, the leader in Indian Kashmir of a breakaway, pro-Pakistan faction of the Hurriyat, sees Kashmiris as victims of a global conspiracy against Muslims, cheated of their rightful incorporation into Pakistan. The talks his former Hurriyat colleagues have opened with Delhi are "meaningless, unnecessary and futile". Similarly, the India-Pakistan dialogue on Kashmir is doomed to "utter failure". "We are not warmongers, not interested in bloodshed," he says, "but India ignored us for 50 years." If the insurgency lasts another 30 years, "it doesn't matter".
India's official position mirrors Pakistan's: it, too, claims the entirety of the old kingdom. But India has long let it be known that it is ready to discuss the permanent division of the state along the old 1949 ceasefire line--roughly the present line of control, on part of which it is now erecting a fence equipped with high-technology sensors. India also has deep-seated objections to ceding Kashmir. As a secular union, it needs its sole Muslim-majority state, and fears that if Kashmir is granted independence or joins Pakistan, other states may want to leave the union as well. 
Many Kashmiris would favour neither Pakistan nor India, but independence. Even short of that, they are outraged that India and Pakistan could contemplate discussing their future with no Kashmiris there. Yasin Malik, leader of the Jammu & Kashmir Liberation Front, a secular nationalist group, is running a signature campaign to demand Kashmiri participation in the talks. "This is not a bilateral issue; not a border dispute," he says, "It is related to the people of Kashmir." He claims to have nearly 1m signatures already, and hopes to secure 2m.
But how many seats at the table? And filled by whom? Sajjad Lone of the People's Conference, a moderate Hurriyat member, says that, in the search for a solution, "Kashmiris have been reduced to an ornamental role, because India and Pakistan have made up, and because of the inherent fragmentation of the Kashmiri leadership." The Hurriyat itself is split. Then there is the PDP government elected in 2002, and the other parties that won votes. Umar Farooq, part of the Hurriyat's delegation to Delhi, concedes that these elected politicians too have constituencies to consider. Then there are the Buddhists of Ladakh and the Hindus of Jammu, who would probably prefer complete incorporation into India. There is also the Hindu minority in the Valley itself, the pandits, most of whom--60,000 families by some estimates--have fled the Valley for fear of anti-Hindu pogroms.
Were Kashmir discussed at such an expanded table, every solution would be unacceptable to somebody. Hurriyat leaders such as Mr Farooq rule out "trifurcation" of the Indian state into its three component parts--in effect, a division along religious lines. Similarly, they would reject the "Chenab" formula, under which the state would be repartitioned along the bed of the Chenab river, which would leave most Kashmiri Muslims in Pakistan. India, rejecting a plebiscite, would be no more amenable to one in which people were asked about the future not of the whole state, but of their own district or sub-district. Nor does it seem ready to contemplate imaginative proposals devised by the America-based Kashmir Study Group. These envisage the reconstitution of part of Kashmir as a "sovereign entity without an international personality"--ie, just short of full independence. 
Flickers of light
There is no public sign that India is prepared to accept anything other than a solution based on the status quo. And as General Musharraf put it last year, in remarks much quoted in Srinagar: "The line of control is why we have had three wars. That is the dispute. It can never be the solution."
So is all the talk of breakthroughs and settlements so much hot air--part of Mr Vajpayee's campaign for victory in elections to be held this spring, and General Musharraf's bid for international respectability? Not quite. Both leaders seem sincere in seeking a peace that is clearly, after all, in both countries' interests. Mr Vajpayee has taken bold political gambles to pursue peace even when unremitting hostility has appeared the safer electoral option. General Musharraf is struggling to prove he is part of America's answer to the scourge of terrorism and not part of the problem. The revelation of Pakistan's involvement in the sale of nuclear secrets to Libya, Iran and North Korea makes it even more imperative to show evidence of good behaviour elsewhere. The general's narrow escapes from two assassination attempts late last year--blamed on extremist Islamists--also highlighted the dangers of pandering to Pakistan's jihadi groups.
In both countries, says Pran Chopra, a veteran Indian journalist and commentator, "the circle of sanity is widening." But neither has done much to prepare public opinion for a climbdown. General Musharraf has said that both sides must shift a bit, and has hinted at dropping Pakistan's insistence on a plebiscite. But each country expects concessions from the other. General Musharraf has to contend with elements of his own army and intelligence services and their jihadi clients, who see Pakistan as incomplete without Kashmir. 
Mr Vajpayee heads a Hindu nationalist party, one of whose platforms has long been the revocation of Kashmir's special status under Article 370. The army in India has never had the clout of its Pakistani counterpart, but it too would find it hard to accept concessions after losing so many lives. An opinion poll in Tehelka, a new weekly newspaper, suggests that 87% of soldiers see the Kashmir problem as one of terrorism, not a freedom struggle.
Even if Indians and Pakistanis could be convinced that peace in Kashmir is worth a few concessions, there remains the difficulty of selling a settlement to disaffected Kashmiris. The Hurriyat's Umar Farooq says India must soon adopt measures to persuade them that this is a serious peace effort. A huge step forward would be the promised opening of a bus route across the line of control, between Srinagar and Muzaffarabad. It raises tricky issues, notably over travel documents, but holds out the promise of a gradual "softening" of the border, allowing Kashmiris to travel, mingle and trade. People-to-people contacts would slowly lessen the importance of political symbols, and India would grant Kashmir greater autonomy. Eventually, India hopes, politicians such as Umar Farooq, the hereditary spiritual leader of the Valley's Sunni Muslims, might be enticed into mainstream Indian politics.
If it works out that way, it would indeed look like an Indian "victory". The difficulty will be to avoid making that look like a Pakistani and Kashmiri defeat.
Caption: For Pakistan, India, or neither, but wanting to be heard

text:
Third time lucky?
THE partition of India in 1947 left not so much a scar as an open wound, and Kashmir is where it still bleeds. Two of the three full-scale wars between India and Pakistan were fought over the divided territory, which is claimed by both countries. Just under half is controlled by India, most of the rest by Pakistan. For the past 14 years, the Indian-ruled Kashmir valley has resembled a police state. India has been fighting an insurgency waged partly by Pakistan-trained militants. The dispute has thwarted all attempts at building normal relations between the two countries. 
The most startling of all the hopes kindled in India at the turn of the year was that all this might be about to change. At a regional summit in Islamabad in January, Mr Vajpayee agreed with Pakistan's president and army chief, Pervez Musharraf, that the two countries should start a "composite dialogue", which, they hoped, "will lead to the settlement of all bilateral issues", including Kashmir.
Such a dream, if realised, would bring enormous benefits to both countries. Most important, it would release Kashmir from its misery, ending a war that has killed at least 40,000 people, possibly many more. Even last year--one of supposedly improving relations and relative peace--the violence cost more than 3,000 lives. A blot on India's international reputation would be removed. Pakistan and India could cut defence spending, a big drain on both their budgets. They could stop frightening the rest of the world with the prospect of a nuclear war: both tested nuclear weapons in 1998, and Pakistan has never ruled out being the first to use them. And they could exploit the almost wholly untapped potential for cross-border trade and investment. 
The breakthrough in Islamabad followed concessions from both sides. India had always resisted even acknowledging the disputed status of Kashmir, and had demanded that Pakistan dismantle "the infrastructure of terrorism" before any dialogue opens. Pakistan, for its part, gave assurances that it would not allow its territory to be used to "support terrorism in any manner"--a reference to its fuelling of the insurgency. If fulfilled, that promise would mean Pakistan's surrendering what it has seen as its only lever over the fate of Kashmir.
This was the culmination of an initiative launched by Mr Vajpayee in April last year in a speech in Srinagar, the summer capital of the Indian state of Jammu & Kashmir. In a remarkable about-turn, he had offered Pakistan the "hand of friendship". Ever since terrorists had attacked the Indian parliament in Delhi in December 2001, and India had accused Pakistan of sponsoring the atrocity, India's hand had been brandished only as a fist. In the course of 2002 the two countries came close to war, with hundreds of thousands of soldiers deployed along the border.
But peace-making has been a consistent theme of Mr Vajpayee's term of office. This was his third (and, he said, final) attempt. The first, in 1999, was scuppered by a Pakistani military adventure in the Kargil area of Kashmir, at a time when General Musharraf had not yet staged the coup that made him president. The second came in 2001, when talks broke down because the two sides refused to make these very same concessions on Kashmir. Undaunted, Mr Vajpayee tried again. He wants to be remembered as a statesman. 
He is also, however, an astute politician, and realised that a peace bid would be popular. This was not self-evident. Mr Vajpayee's victory in the most recent general election in 1999 owed much to India's victory in the undeclared Kargil war; in elections in Gujarat in December 2002, his BJP had sailed to victory on a campaign full of vilification of Pakistan. But Mr Vajpayee recognised a national weariness with the constant sparring. Over the summer and autumn of last year, a series of confidence-building measures and of "people-to-people contacts" reminded both countries how much they had in common.
Nevertheless, Mr Vajpayee made his offer from what India saw as a position of strength. A state election in Kashmir in 2002 had, unusually, not been rigged, and although the turnout was low, the new state government, committed to a "healing touch", had a greater claim to legitimacy than the previous regime. Speaking in Srinagar, the prime minister was reaffirming that this was Indian territory, and would remain so, even if the fighting continued. Debilitating though the war has been, India is a big country and believes that, if necessary, it can fight low-level wars on its periphery indefinitely.
Mr Vajpayee's chief motive in making his friendly overtures was to embarrass Pakistan into reciprocating. Pakistan took its time, but eventually began to respond more enthusiastically to the confidence-building measures, such as the restoration of diplomatic relations and of air, road and rail links, all cut since the attack on parliament. Most significantly, it agreed to discuss the opening of a bus route across the "line of control" that divides Kashmir in the absence of an agreed international border (see map, previous page). 
In November, Pakistan offered a ceasefire along the line of control. Indian officials believe shooting over the border is often a cover for infiltration by militant fighters. In the winter the snow in the high mountain passes stops most traffic anyway, but India says that this winter hardly any militants are crossing. General Musharraf has even suggested (and his officials have denied) that Pakistan might "set aside" its insistence on the implementation of a United Nations resolution calling for a plebiscite in Kashmir on its future.
Musharraf's gamble
General Musharraf is constrained by popular opinion. Pakistan's Islamist parties, for some of which jihad in Kashmir is a sacred national quest, have been buoyed by a tide of anti-Americanism since the much-resented war in Afghanistan in 2001. The militants also have sympathisers in General Musharraf's own army and intelligence services. Having already taken the risk of backing America in Afghanistan against Pakistan's former allies, to renounce the claim on Kashmir would be suicidal--politically, and perhaps literally as well. In December 2003 General Musharraf narrowly escaped two assassination attempts.
He was also, however, under discreet international pressure from his most important foreign backers--America and China--to prove himself a responsible international citizen. That pressure intensified following revelations that linked Pakistani scientists to nuclear proliferation in North Korea, Iran and Libya. General Musharraf may also see Mr Vajpayee, who is 79, as the only Indian statesman capable of crafting a deal that both allows Pakistan some dignity and placates nationalist hardliners in the BJP. The assassination attempts demonstrated the futility of trying to reconcile the international "war against terrorism" with clandestine support for jihadis in Kashmir.
The would-be assassins seem also to have persuaded Indian officials that General Musharraf represents their best hope of a deal. Since the Kargil war, India has never trusted him, but it now believes that were he killed, whoever replaces him is likely to be less accommodating.
So the chances of progress, if not of a resolution, look better than they have done for years. In January, parallel talks opened between the Indian government and the more moderate of Kashmir's separatist leaders. But Indian and Pakistani leaders have been here before. Peace is vulnerable to atrocities by extremists on both sides: a stepping up of infiltration when the snows melt; a Pakistani-sponsored terrorist attack elsewhere in India; or another pogrom directed at India's Muslim minority, like that in Gujarat in March 2002. The process could also be disrupted if assassination, infirmity or an election removes either General Musharraf or Mr Vajpayee from the scene.
Agreeing to talk, moreover, is no more than that. Old habits of thought will be hard to change. Many Indians believe that, sooner or later, Pakistan's soldiers or spies will intervene to thwart peace. Similarly, many Pakistanis believe India wants nothing short of their country's national annihilation. The cynical view is that Mr Vajpayee has bought himself a few months in which he can win an election as a peacemaker, confident that, if his fling with General Musharraf ends in tears, no one will blame him anyway.
In many Indian eyes, a solution to the Kashmir tangle is straightforward: India would drop its claim to Pakistani-occupied Kashmir; Pakistan would do the same for the Indian part; the line of control would gradually become an international border; and India would grant Kashmir greater autonomy. This would deny self-determination to Kashmiris, many of whom want independence from both Pakistan and India. But it would meet India's requirement that no separatist precedent be set for other restive regions, and that its one state with a Muslim majority remain in the Union.
However, such a deal, requiring India to give up only what it does not have, has in the past always foundered on the rock of Pakistani Islamic nationalism. The difficulty will be to keep Kashmir on the agenda, as Pakistan insists, without confronting the hardest issues until a real constituency for peace has been built in both countries.
Coming out
In the cavernous corridors of Delhi's South Block, housing the foreign ministry, Indian diplomats are on a roll. Besides progress towards peace with Pakistan, they are cheering moves towards regional integration and advances in their other two most important bilateral relationships, with America and China.
The breakthrough with Pakistan came at a meeting of the South Asian Association for Regional Co-operation (SAARC), a body rendered largely useless by the unremitting hostility between its two biggest economies. This time, however, it did agree to establish a regional free-trade area from 2006, and Mr Vajpayee is even speaking dreamily about open regional borders, economic union and a single currency, on the model of the European Union. That seems far-fetched. A more modest ambition, however, of a network of co-operative arrangements that raise the price of war, sounds achievable. 
The dreadful punctuation mark left by the September 11th attacks on America interrupted one of the unfolding stories of the post-cold-war world: a gradual shift in American allegiance from one Asian giant--communist, dictatorial, mercantilist China--to another--democratic, liberal, economically unthreatening India. In late 2001, America, to India's bewilderment, found itself locked in an embrace with Pakistan. Yashwant Sinha, India's foreign minister, says India never asks the United States to exert pressure, but that "if there is a state which is sponsoring terrorism, then the world has a responsibility to the state which is a victim."
Relations were complicated further when India refused to send soldiers to Iraq. In a country where traditions of anti-imperialism, third-world solidarity and non-violence run deep, the refusal was less surprising than the voices in the BJP arguing for Indian participation, seeing a chance to make common cause with the superpower against terrorist Muslims. On other issues, India has already shown a pragmatic willingness to pursue its perceived national interest at the expense of its "traditional" values. Its support for Tibet, for example, whose spiritual leader, the Dalai Lama, has been in exile in India since 1959, has become weaker as relations with China have become more important. And India maintains good links with the generals in Myanmar who throttled the country's democratic movement.
Despite differences over Iraq and Pakistan, however, relations with America are probably, as Mr Sinha boasts, better than ever. Sanctions imposed on India after its nuclear test have been lifted; in January a long-awaited agreement was reached on trade in "dual-use" technologies (ie, with a military as well as a civilian application); and co-operation on civilian nuclear technologies, space and missile defence was hailed as taking "strategic partnership" to new heights. Similarly, last year saw big strides towards improving the prickly relations with China, which humiliated India in a border war in 1962. Long-running talks on the huge territorial dispute have for the first time gained serious momentum.
"The India that can't say yes", a phrase used by Stephen Cohen, an American academic, sums up the difficulties foreigners have had in dealing with the place. But now it is recognised, says Mr Sinha, with some justification, as a leading nation on all fronts. As in its early days of independence, India is "ready once again to engage with the world". He is optimistic that support is growing for one cherished Indian ambition: a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council. India, long condescended to as an "inefficient democracy", is now earning credit for its achievements and is ready to "cash the democracy dividend".

text:
After a run of troublesome years, has "India's decade" dawned at last? Simon Long reviews the prospects
ONLY a year ago, India seemed in a sorry state. Tension with Pakistan had recently reached such a pitch that nuclear war did not seem inconceivable. An Indian state, Gujarat, had witnessed appalling communal violence between Hindus and Muslims. The economy, after years of drought, was limping along at an annual growth rate of just 4%, not enough to change the fortunes of a nation of a billion people, a quarter of them living in severe poverty.
One year on, in the phrase of its government's propaganda campaign, "India is shining". The risk of war seems remote and a historic settlement with Pakistan seems possible. Recent state election campaigns have been marked not by communal antagonism, but voters' mature disgruntlement over bad and corrupt government, pot-holed roads, poisonous water and meagre power supplies. The economy, blessed by a lavish monsoon, is growing by 8% a year or more. Hotels are full of foreigners newly alive to India's potential as both a market and an "outsourcing" destination. India fared well in a cricket series in Australia. Indian politicians, businessmen, diplomats and journalists are relishing the new sense of self-confidence. India, said to have been "emerging" for years, has at last come out. This is India's decade, crow the optimists; India's century, echo true patriots.
These are big hopes on the back of a solitary good year, and caution is advisable. After a dozen years of opening up and liberalising, India's economy is still relatively small by global measures. With 17% of the world's people, it accounts for less than 2% of global GDP and 1% of world trade. To take the most obvious comparison, China last year saw an increase in its two-way trade with the world of roughly double India's total trade.
Making electoral hay
Indian exuberance is tinged with the rhetoric of an electoral contest. So good are Indians believed to feel about themselves and their government that the prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, has decided to bring forward the general election due by October to this spring. It is only natural that he should be talking up India's prospects, and that his finance minister, Jaswant Singh, should be sprinkling tax cuts and spending promises as if from a bottomless well.
India is a country of extremes, and prone to extreme views about itself. This survey will examine the origins of the present buoyant optimism, and conclude that much of it is overdone: or at least, based on hope rather than achievement. Nor was India in quite such a mess a year ago as the pessimists feared. For a decade, the economy had seen average real growth in GDP of about 6% a year. The hope now is that it is about to take off on a markedly steeper growth path of 8% a year or more, and keep it up.
That sort of acceleration is necessary to provide opportunities for India's growing population and its even-faster-growing workforce. During the present decade, on one estimate India's labour force will expand by 50% more than all of East Asia's (including China's) put together. Without further structural reform, such a growth spurt seems unlikely. But this survey will argue that this is indeed a moment of shining economic opportunity for India, and that if Mr Vajpayee's Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) succeeds in leading its coalition to another election victory, it should be better placed to take advantage of it, and pursue the necessary reform, than has been any government in recent years.
Shining brighter, however, than any GDP growth target is the prospect of some lasting reconciliation with the twin from which India was so bloodily separated at birth in 1947.
