text:
A catastrophe for the ruling party need not spell the end of reform
THE results were still coming in as The Economist went to press on May 13th, but India's government has suffered a stunning reversal. Even the gloomiest of the exit and opinion polls had envisaged that the ruling coalition, led by the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), would lose only a couple of dozen seats, which it was expected easily to make up by wooing a few more small parties into its camp. Nobody expected the Congress party to come out on top--and that goes for Congress's own leadership. Yet this is what has happened. The Congress leader, Sonia Gandhi, relentlessly mocked by the BJP for her Italian origins, could well be the next prime minister of India--though there will be many days of horse-trading to get through first, since Congress is far from being able to form a government on its own, and will need the support of a disparate crew of left-wing and low-caste parties.
The BJP had felt sure of victory. With estimated growth in the year to March 2004 of more than 8%, a seemingly popular leader and greatly improved relations with Pakistan to boast of, its record looked hard to beat: they called it "India Shining". In the past year or so, after all, India has increasingly been seen abroad as having become a sort of China-in-preparation, poised to embark on the same sort of foreign-investment-led growth that has transformed that other giant.
To many Indians, though, things did not look like that. The exceptional growth in the year just ended, based in part on a favourable monsoon, followed four years of near-drought which has hit rural voters, still the great majority, hard. Peace with Pakistan is all very well, but comes far down the list of priorities for Indian villagers, below more pressing matters such as supplies of clean water and electricity. The probable cause of the BJP's calamity is a simple old-fashioned anti-incumbency vote. To that, though, one must add something else. The religious riots of 2002, in which up to 2,000 Muslims died, took place in a state, Gujarat, governed by the BJP. Although India's Supreme Court castigated Narendra Modi, the BJP's chief minister, for failing to do anything to prevent the massacre, he has never been disciplined, remains senior in the BJP's leadership and was deployed to campaign in the election. Though it projects itself as a modern, reformist party, the BJP's roots lie in Hindu fundamentalism and the worst sort of intolerance. Atal Behari Vajpayee, the BJP leader and prime minister until he resigned on May 13th, may be widely liked, but behind him lurk Mr Modi and his kind.
Is the BJP's defeat a serious setback for economic reform in India? Not necessarily. The BJP has no monopoly on reform: indeed, the party was, historically, a tardy convert to a cause first championed by Congress's late leader, Rajiv Gandhi, and put into practice by the Congress government that took power after his assassination in 1991. text:
A stunning defeat for the ruling party
BAD for the credibility of almost every pundit and pollster; bad for political stability; even perhaps bad for economic reform. But the outcome of India's election has been a triumph for democracy, and the ordinary voter's refusal, after being subjected to months of self-congratulatory government propaganda about "India Shining", to accept rhetoric over results. As The Economist went to press on May 13th, some of the 370m votes cast in the protracted three-week election were still to be counted, and the shape of the new government was yet to emerge from the political fog. But the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) had lost. The prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, had visited the president and handed in his resignation.
An alliance led by the main opposition party, Congress, seemed likely to have won nearly 220 out of the 543 contested seats. The BJP-led coalition, the National Democratic Alliance (NDA), would have about 190. A "Left Front", dominated by the Communists, had recorded its best-ever performance, and would have more than 60 seats. Since the Left's main priority is to oust the BJP, a coalition grouped around Congress seemed the most likely new government. Congress's leader, Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born widow of a former prime minister, has been scorned by the BJP for her foreign origins and political cackhandedness. She has, however, had the last laugh. Her party has increased its number of seats from 112 to nearly 150--a number beyond its dreams even a month ago, and probably a few seats more than the BJP won. She is now first in line for a chance to become prime minister.
The prospect of a period of political jockeying and potential instability will worry investors, who also fear that the election will be taken as a popular rejection of the liberalising reforms of the Indian economy, recently championed by the BJP. In two state-assembly elections held simultaneously, well-known reformist leaders have been ousted. 
Chandrababu Naidu, the chief minister of Andhra Pradesh, was a darling of development banks and the press for his commitment to fiscal discipline, social reform in the countryside, and, above all, information technology and e-government. He helped turn the state capital, Hyderabad, into one of India's IT hubs, but was swept out of power in a landslide. Congress's S.M. Krishna, chief minister of neighbouring Karnataka, where the software boom has not spread its benefits far beyond the capital, Bangalore, also lost and quit--so this is not just party politics.
Such is the strength in India of the "anti-incumbency" vote that Karnataka is in fact one of the few states where the BJP has fared well. One of its few consolations is to have established this foothold in the south, and to advance progress towards its goal of becoming, like Congress, a truly national party. A lavish monsoon last year was an important contributor to India's soaring rate of economic growth, of more than 8% this year, and to what the BJP misdiagnosed as a national "feel-good factor". But Andhra Pradesh and Karnataka suffered yet another year of drought. There, the shortage of water mattered far more to most voters than the latest call-centre.
Similar considerations, on a national level, weighed against the BJP itself. It has lost more than 40 of its 182 seats. Encouraged by a good showing in state elections last December, BJP strategists had persuaded Mr Vajpayee to call elections a few months early. They argued that the BJP should capitalise on the economic boom, and on the unrivalled prestige enjoyed by the prime minister himself. 
His drive to build a lasting peace with Pakistan was hugely popular; but it has weighed little with voters. Indeed, the entire "India Shining" campaign had little resonance for the two out of three of India's 670m voters who live in the countryside, and remember the bad years that preceded the last, abundant monsoon. Their disillusionment was reflected in what was by Indian standards a low turn-out of around 55%. Their villages have seen little improvement in roads, electricity and water supply. A quarter of India's people still live in severe poverty. 
The BJP's boosterish rhetoric backfired, and towards the end of its campaign was jettisoned in favour of a stress on the virtues of continuity and stability. 
Before the vote, the NDA lost some important members, and others have fared badly, notably the BJP's biggest ally, Mr Naidu's Telugu Desam Party (TDP) whose 29 seats in parliament have dwindled to just a handful. Another disaster hit the NDA in the southern state of Tamil Nadu, where its former member, the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam (DMK), routed the BJP's coalition partner.
Drawn and quartered
Congress, for its part, traditionally too proud for grubby coalition politics, had this time assembled an impressive haul of allies. But parliament will be hung, and to form a government it will still need the support of the left, and perhaps of one or two other uncommitted parties, of which the biggest are Samajwadi and the Bahujan Samaj, two lower-caste based parties with their strength in India's largest state, Uttar Pradesh. Some of these potential partners may balk at supporting Mrs Gandhi as prime minister. One rumoured alternative from within Congress is Manmohan Singh, a respected former finance minister.
An unstable coalition government, relying on the support of the Communists, is unlikely to prove radical, and may be short-lived. But the presence of Mr Singh in Congress--as a senior policymaker, at any rate, if not in the top job--is one reason for guarded optimism that the election result will not mean the stalling of economic reform. It was Mr Singh who launched the opening up and liberalisation of the economy in 1991. Congress's manifesto commits it to a policy of sustaining and even accelerating current rates of economic growth. That will not be possible without more reform: cutting the fiscal deficit; continuing to foster competition; privatising more state-run enterprises.
There are other reasons for cheer. First, one of Mr Vajpayee's dreams commands consensus support and will surely still be followed: building a lasting peace with Pakistan, a project dear to Congress the last time it was in power. Second, the electoral rebuke for the BJP from rural India might intensify efforts to spread some of the alleged shine to the gloomier parts of the countryside. Properly interpreted, it should not thwart reform, but spur it.

text:
A sequence of unexpected events has given India its most reformist prime minister ever
SINCE nobody, and certainly not Sonia Gandhi herself, imagined the Congress party would win India's election, it is hardly surprising that the past week has been, to put it mildly, confusing. But on May 19th, a week after the election result and a whole month after polling started, it at last was clear that Mrs Gandhi would not consent to be sworn in as prime minister, all attempts by the party to change her mind having failed. In her place, the new prime minister is to be Manmohan Singh, the architect of India's economic reforms in the early 1990s. He will head a coalition government that is itself in a minority in parliament. Not much else was clear as The Economist went to press: not the make-up of Mr Singh's coalition cabinet; nor the details of the common platform he will be obliged to adhere to if he is to retain the backing of India's Communist parties, on whose support he depends; nor the implications for Pakistan and peace. Little wonder that traders have been making hay, driving the Mumbai stockmarket down a panicky 11% on May 17th, then up a happier 8% the day after.
The worries relate mainly to the fate of India's economic reform under the new management. But the markets should relax a little. In 1991, when Congress last took office, it was in an almost identical position to the one it finds itself in now: short of a majority, and forced to depend on the support of Communists from outside its coalition. Then, as now, Mr Singh was the chief reformer, though the party was led by P.V. Narasimha Rao, a septuagenarian poet with, at the time, no known enthusiasm or aptitude for reform. All the same, the Rao/Singh government lasted five years, during which it smashed the "licence raj" that had smothered the economy in regulations and condemned it to the sluggish "Hindu rate of growth", a term now happily consigned to history. That government started to privatise, opened India to foreign investment and began to deregulate the country's appalling infrastructure. Over the past six years, the ruling Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) merely continued Congress's work, with plenty of backtracking along the way. By the time of this latest election, the BJP's privatisation programme was restricted to selling off minority stakes in profitable businesses to eager buyers.
This suggests that there is plenty of reason to hope for better from the new team. As for the Communists, they should be judged by what they do, not what they say. In West Bengal, where Communists run the state government, 15 state-owned enterprises are being sold off, and IT companies have been designated as "strategic", meaning that their workers are banned from striking. Despite dismissing Congress economic policy as no better than the Hindu nationalists of the BJP, the Communists have worked with Congress before, and should have no difficulty doing so again.
The real problem is that the Communists have chosen to remain outside a new government. Joining would have entitled them to cabinet representation and provided a chance to put some of the good ideas they have followed at state level--on local democracy, health care and literacy--into practice throughout India. The policies of these parties need not clash with reform. The proceeds of rapid privatisation could, for example, be invested in the sort of grass-roots human development that has worked so well in Kerala, where the Communists are strong. That would appeal to both sides of the coalition, and to foreign investors as well. Sadly, the Communists put local interests first (they are rivals to Congress in two key states), and so chose to stay out. But with luck, the result could be the same: bolder deregulation, combined with more attention to the 700m Indians who live in rural areas, far from call centres and cappuccino bars. This is precisely Mr Singh's philosophy: that government should remove itself from all of the things it does not do well, which means pretty much anything to do with business, and concentrate its efforts on areas where markets alone do not provide the answers.
As Mr Singh's chances waxed during the week, the Bombay exchange rapidly recovered from its fright. And well it might. Whereas the BJP were always reluctant reformers, Mr Singh is the genuine article, a man who understands better than any other leading Indian politician the scope of what still needs to be done. This needs to include plenty more privatisation, tackling taboos such as the oil companies, the national airline and the banks. The essential but delicate task of chipping away at India's mountain of inefficient subsidies--which would allow vast sums to be spent instead on improving India's physical and human infrastructure--has not even been started. Most pressing of all is the country's fiscal mess: its deficit runs at 10% of GDP and absorbs far too much of its budget. But reducing this will be tough: neither widening the tax base nor cutting spending looks easy, especially with the Communists to convince. Still, Mr Singh has performed miracles before. When he took over as finance minister in 1991, India's foreign exchange reserves had sunk to $1.2 billion, or three weeks of imports. When he left office in 1996, they stood at $18 billion, and the economy had grown by an average of 5.6% during those years, far better than before.
Politics turn sour
Ideally, Mr Singh would be able to rely on help from the BJP, which says that it wants all these things too. In reality, this is highly unlikely. For there is not much doubting that Indian politics have taken a nasty and confrontational turn. The BJP's hysterical reaction to the prospect of Mrs Gandhi's appointment has, if nothing else, revealed just what an unpleasant and xenophobic party it fundamentally is, despite the appearance of moderation in which Atal Behari Vajpayee cloaked it. It is true that in most countries a foreign-born leader would be hard to imagine. In America it would be illegal. But India's constitution explicitly permits it, and the issue had been thoroughly ventilated before the voters had their say.
Nor is Mrs Gandhi just any foreigner: she lost both her husband and her beloved mother-in-law, both prime ministers of India, to assassins. In the recent election campaign she showed herself well able to run rings around the BJP, and its boast of a "shining" India, in fluent Hindi. To boycott her swearing-in, as the BJP threatened, shows a contempt for the democracy that is India's proudest achievement. And it was, incidentally, a trifle odd for L.K. Advani, the BJP's leading hard-liner and the former deputy prime minister, to have been part of the boycott planned if she became prime minister. He was born in Karachi (though it was part of British India at the time).
Unfortunately, this may be only the beginning of the BJP's return to bad old ways. Already, voices within the ranks of the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, the Hindu-nationalist mass movement on which the BJP depends, are blaming the loss of the election on insufficient promotion of Hindutva, or "Hinduness". What does this actually mean? On past evidence, more revision of school textbooks to deny the contributions that the Muslims have made to India; more pressure to tear down mosques and replace them with temples; an end to the "special" autonomous status of Kashmir, for what that is worth; and ultimately, one may be sure, more blood.
Even if the rabid element in the BJP can be restrained on these points, there is reason to fear that another casualty of the election may well be the welcome detente with Pakistan that Mr Vajpayee engineered. If it is to last beyond August, when the two countries' foreign ministers are to meet, and when the status of Kashmir will need to be discussed, Pakistan needs to be given a few concessions. But if hard-liners are ascendant in the BJP it may be difficult for a minority Congress government to grant them. On the other hand, Mr Singh is a Sikh, and Sikhs occupy a special position in the subcontinent, because their religion draws on both Islam and Hinduism. That might just qualify him to make a historic breakthrough. Should Pakistan and India go back to raining abuse, or shells, on each other, the new prime minister's ambition to make this the "Indian century" will become very much harder to achieve.

text:
Reformist idealism confronts grubby reality 
THE glad confident morning has passed. After the Congress party confounded expectations by winning India's election, and its leader, Sonia Gandhi, compounded the astonishment by turning down the office of prime minister, Indian politics was briefly suffused with notions of noble sacrifice and reformist idealism. Within hours, however, it was back to the murkier business of politics as usual; rewards for the loyal; sops for the proud; portfolios for the power-hungry. 
Mrs Gandhi's nominee to run the government, Manmohan Singh, is dignified and cerebral, and enjoys both a reputation for scrupulous honesty and impeccable reformist credentials. Sadly, those are not the qualities needed for forming, or running, a coalition government. Like sheepdogs corralling an unruly flock only to find that there is always one outside the pen ambling towards a cliff, Congress henchmen are already struggling to keep their new coalition, known as the United Progressive Alliance (UPA), together through its very first challenge: forming the 68-member administration.
First to bolt was Laloo Prasad Yadav, of the Rashtriya Janata Dal, the longest-standing of Congress's coalition partners, and, with 23 of parliament's 545 seats, the biggest. Mr Yadav apparently thought these virtues merited a big job, namely home minister. This would have been embarrassing: he faces a number of charges of involvement in a massive corruption scandal in his state, Bihar. Mr Yadav was placated by being made minister for railways. This, too, is an important job: Indian Railways is by some measures the world's largest commercial organisation (though it would help if passengers in places such as Bihar paid fares). Another Congress ally wanted the post and is now in a huff.
The next biggest coalition partner, the Dravida Munnetra Kazhagam, from the southern state of Tamil Nadu, then threw a tantrum because it was not given the portfolios it had been promised. Its seven ministers refused to be sworn in until this "mistake" was corrected, in a shuffle that saw the first appointee as shipping minister, K. Chandrashekhar Rao, stand down. Mr Rao had a price, however: a promise of help for his party's one demand, that a separate state, called Telengana, be carved out of Andhra Pradesh.
Since Congress holds only 145 seats on its own, this wrangling raises doubts about the government's stability. But Shaibal Gupta, an analyst at the Asian Development Research Institute, in Patna in Bihar, argues it is more solid than it looks. It will be held together by a fear of the return of the last government, led by the Hindu-nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, and by the worry that in a snap election Congress might do even better at its partners' expense. Mrs Gandhi's act of renunciation is thought to be a vote-winner.
Policy differences are another worry, especially since the coalition will rely on the "outside support" of a 59-seat-strong Left Front, dominated by the Communists. Mr Singh is seen as the father of India's economic-reform programme ()see page 80 as finance minister in the early 1990s. That portfolio has now gone to another former incumbent, Palaniappan Chidambaram, also known as an ardent reformer. The Communists demanded changes in the UPA's "common minimum programme", released on May 27th, even though they are not signatories.
In two areas, the Communists have acted as a brake: radical reform of India's over-protective labour laws, a big deterrent to investment; and the privatisation of most money-making state enterprises. Congress's partners have also secured a commitment to the repeal of much-abused anti-terrorist legislation. On the whole, however, the programme reflects Congress's own agenda. It aims for annual economic growth of 7-8% through continued economic liberalisation.
The surprising strength of Congress's position can be seen in its success in holding on to the finance and three other most important portfolios. This also shows the influence of Mrs Gandhi herself. The foreign, home and defence ministers are all Gandhi-family loyalists. One of them, Shivraj Patil, the home minister, actually lost the election. He will join the prime minister and the new foreign minister, Natwar Singh, in the nominated and indirectly-elected upper house of parliament.
As well as leading Congress nationally, Mrs Gandhi leads the parliamentary party and the UPA, and there have been fears of a confusion between two "power centres". However, her new-found prestige and newly-recognised political skills should actually strengthen the government. Still, the fact that only two of the top five positions are held by directly elected politicians may prove a liability. It is worrying, too, that two of the five are septuagenarians, and two more are 68.
Such is Mrs Gandhi's standing that Pakistan's president, Pervez Musharraf, has invited her to visit. Both Natwar Singh and the new national-security adviser, J.N. Dixit, are former diplomats who served in Pakistan. Congress backed the peace initiative launched last year by the former prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee. It now has to manage a series of technical talks, leading up to a meeting between foreign ministers in August, covering all issues, including the hardest of all--Kashmir. But Congress insists on taking an agreement signed in Simla in 1972 as a starting-point. That implies legitimising the status quo in Kashmir, and is unlikely to appeal to General Musharraf, a man Natwar Singh last year described as "a one-dimensional individual, obsessed with Kashmir". What is needed is a victory for hope over all the bitter experience embodied in India's new foreign-policy team.

text:
An ousted ruling party looks for scapegoats and saviours
LIKE mourners bickering at a funeral, members of the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) are busily apportioning blame for their surprise defeat in the elections held in India in April and May. They are also squabbling over its future direction and leadership, and over how to handle a revolt in the ranks in the state of Gujarat against the leadership of Narendra Modi, the chief minister, and most controversial of all BJP politicians.
On one side are those who think the party needs to broaden its appeal as a moderate, centrist, force. On the other are those who want the BJP to reassert its identity as the champion of India's Hindu majority. The BJP is the political branch of a "family" of Hindu organisations, whose parent is the Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS). Many within the RSS believe that the election was lost because not enough attention was paid to the movement's core purpose, the promotion of Hindutva, or "Hinduness".
The former prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, seen as a moderate, managed to keep these different strands together during the party's six years in government, but he is 79 and retreating from the front line. He will remain chairman of the BJP's parliamentary party and of the National Democratic Alliance, the coalition of a dozen parties it led in the outgoing government. But the formal leader of the opposition--and, as the leader of the BJP's parliamentary group, its most public face--will now be Lal Krishna Advani, who was Mr Vajpayee's deputy prime minister.
Mr Advani is trying to live down his image as a tub-thumping hardliner. In the early 1990s, he dragged the BJP from the political fringes to the verge of national power by leading a divisive campaign for the construction of a Hindu temple in Ayodhya, where a mosque then stood. He is 76 and so presumably cannot hope to be more than an interim leader. But who could succeed him? 
A number of younger politicians, jostling for prominence, have suffered setbacks. Sushma Swaraj, the outgoing health minister, became a figure of fun after promising to shave her head if Sonia Gandhi, the Italian-born leader of the ruling Congress party, became prime minister. Pramod Mahajan, a BJP general secretary, and Arun Jaitley, the former commerce minister, were seen as brilliant political strategists. Yet the BJP's election campaign, boasting of economic successes invisible to many voters, was a disaster. 
Moreover, none of these is an elected politician with a mass power base. Gujarat's Mr Modi, on the other hand, led the BJP to a landslide in state elections in 2002, and has a devoted following among hardcore BJP and RSS activists. However, he is loathed and feared by India's large Muslim minority and by liberals across the country. His government was accused of complicity in anti-Muslim riots in Gujarat in 2002, when perhaps 2,000 people were killed. Not a single murder has since led to a conviction. In April, the country's Supreme Court called Mr Modi's government "modern-day Neros", and accused it of having "sympathies more for the accused than the victims".
Nationally, although Mr Vajpayee has blamed complacency rather than Gujarat for the NDA's poor electoral showing, not all his alliance partners agree. That, however, is not why Mr Modi is in political trouble. In the parliamentary elections, the BJP's share of Gujarat's 26 seats fell from 20 to 14, and he has since faced a rebellion from 62 of the BJP's 127 members of the state assembly against what Rajendrasinh Rana, the BJP's state president, calls his "autocratic type of functioning". 
His problems stem in part not from alleged bigotry but from economic reformism. A powerful RSS-affiliated farmers' organisation has turned on him for raising electricity tariffs. In the past, Gujarat, like some other states, has courted bankruptcy by doling out free power. 
Many observers in Gujarat think Mr Modi is on his way out--if not imminently, then later this year after state elections in neighbouring Maharashtra. He still, however, has loyalists. S.K. Modi (no relation), his authorised biographer, thinks the BJP lost not because of its perceived extremism but its moderation--a policy of "appeasement" of minorities such as Muslims--that has made it indistinguishable from the Congress party. 
This, he says, has disillusioned party workers and undermined campaigning. Worse could follow: "The whole BJP will collapse if Narendra Modi goes." That is an exaggeration, no doubt. But it highlights the party's real dilemma, for it needs both the votes of moderates and the zeal of the extremists.

text:
Though detente survives India's election, a Kashmir peace is still elusive
CHANGING partners is never entirely easy. The peace process between India and Pakistan has endured something of a rocky patch since its principal architect, Atal Behari Vajpayee, India's former prime minister, lost an election last month. A flurry of meetings with the new Congress-party led government has now reassured Pakistan that India remains committed to the path of dialogue. What remains in doubt is whether that path actually leads anywhere.
On June 20th, officials from the two countries produced a joint statement on measures to build confidence over their respective nuclear arsenals. This was part of a series of talks agreed to in February, covering all bilateral disputes, including the intertwined issues of terrorism and Kashmir, which seemed to bring the neighbours to the brink of war in 2002. 
The day after the talks, India's new foreign minister, Natwar Singh, and his Pakistani counterpart, Khurshid Kasuri, had a chummy lunch on the margins of a regional conference in Qingdao, China. Progress was also being made in talks about a contentious hydro-electric project in Indian-administered Kashmir. On June 27th, the heads of the countries' diplomatic services are to meet and broach the subject of Kashmir. The foreign ministers will meet again next month at another conference, and then, in August, sit down for serious bilateral talks to review progress so far.
In opposition, the Congress party last year supported Mr Vajpayee's offer of the "hand of friendship" to Pakistan. Pakistani officials were at first nonetheless suspicious of the new government's foreign-policy team. It is dominated by crusty former diplomats, such as Mr Singh himself, who rattled Pakistan by making repeated references to the 1972 Simla agreement between the two countries. In Islamabad, this was taken to mean that India ruled out any change in its policy on Kashmir. 
Mr Singh has since backed down, or, as his officials prefer it, cleared up the misunderstanding caused by inaccurate reporting of his remarks. After initial misgivings, says Khalid Mahmud of the Institute of Regional Studies, a think-tank in Islamabad, Pakistan has now concluded that Congress may actually prove to be a more consistent partner than was the whimsical Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP) with its occasional warmongering.
So the marked improvement in relations seen in the final months of the BJP government persists. The problem is that little concrete has been achieved so far. The risk-reduction agreement covering nuclear weapons is welcomed by foreign governments worried about the risks of nuclear accidents, or of the rapid escalation of a conventional war. But it is largely symbolic. With the exception of an agreement to set up a new telephone hotline between the two foreign ministries (in itself only of symbolic value), it mostly formalises existing practice. This includes a moratorium on further nuclear explosions, and arrangements for one side notifying the other of missile tests. 
Such confidence-building measures will not satisfy Pakistan for long if there continues to be little sign that India is prepared to talk seriously about Kashmir. And, despite weariness with the 15-year long war, the moderate separatists in Kashmir itself, who are prepared at present to talk to India, may also lose patience. 
India acknowledges that far fewer militants are infiltrating Indian-controlled Kashmir, but claims that 4,000 are camped on the Pakistani side ready to cross, now the snows have melted. Even without them, the violence continues. According to India's own figures, 1,000 people were killed in the first five months of the year. The risks taken by moderates were highlighted on May 29th by the killing in a mosque in Srinagar, the state's summer capital, of Mushtaq Ahmed. He was cousin and close adviser to Umar Farooq, a senior cleric and part of a group of separatist leaders who have been engaged in talks with the Delhi government.
That dialogue, started in January, has been stalled because of the elections. India's home minister, Shivraj Patil, has acknowledged that India needs to reward separatists prepared to talk peace. But the government will not want to lay itself open to charges of being soft on terrorism. Already, the BJP has attacked this aspect of its policy. At its national-executive meeting this week in Mumbai, the moderate Mr Vajpayee hinted at retirement, while hardliners reasserted the party's Hindu-nationalist roots. That means promoting "Hindutva" or "Hinduness". It also usually means bashing Pakistan.

text:
The principle of peaceful coexistence: keep talking as long as possible
AMONG the mementoes Natwar Singh, India's foreign minister, shows visitors is a photograph taken in Beijing in 1957. It captures him as a young diplomat, alongside Mao Zedong and other Chinese leaders. It is a souvenir of a lost era of third-world solidarity, when India and China devised and embraced their "five principles of peaceful coexistence", whose 50th anniversary was celebrated in June. In 1962 they flouted them all by fighting a brief, bloody border war. China routed India, which has sulked ever since. Relations may now be on the point of recovery, though the "brotherhood" the giant Asian neighbours asserted in the 1950s remains a distant memory.
In Delhi this week, J.N. Dixit, India's national-security advisor, and Dai Bingguo, a Chinese deputy foreign minister, held two days of talks on the border dispute. Such discussions have a history dating back to 1981. A joint working group on the issue was formed in 1988. It made little progress, but allowed relations to improve in other ways. Last year Atal Behari Vajpayee, then India's prime minister, visited China and gave the talks new momentum. They were elevated from an exercise in cartographic quarrelling by officials to a "political dialogue", intended, presumably, to reach a conclusion. This is the third round, but the first since India's new government, led by the Congress party, took office in May.
There was no breakthrough, but China has been reassured that the new government wants to continue a steady improvement in ties. This has been led by business. Just a couple of years ago, Indian firms were fretting about losing market share to China. Now many see opportunities as well as threats. In the first five months of this year, Indian exports to China more than doubled compared with the same period last year, to $3.6 billion, while imports from China grew by more than half, to $1.9 billion. C. Raja Mohan, an analyst at Delhi's Jawarhalal Nehru University, sees vast potential as relations develop. Calcutta (now Kolkata), he points out, was once the port for Lhasa, capital of Tibet.
Regional and global politics also favour closer ties. Both countries, though keen to pursue better relations with America, are wary of its global dominance. China has moderated its traditional backing for Pakistan and its claim on Kashmir. Indeed, China has been exasperated by Pakistani provocations in Kashmir in recent years, and by the Islamic militants who sneak from Pakistan to its own Muslim-dominated western region of Xinjiang.
The outlines of a border deal have been clear for decades. India would cede its claim to an area of Ladakh in Kashmir, almost the size of Switzerland, occupied by China and of strategic importance to it. In return, China would accept Indian sovereignty over an area nearly three times larger, the state of Arunachal Pradesh. In each sector, some adjustments would be made. This would help spare India's blushes at a settlement it fought to thwart, and let China say it had not accepted a border imposed by British imperialists. 
India, a raucous democracy, would have more trouble selling such a trade-off at home. In the military and intelligence establishments some are still thankful for the God-given barrier formed by the Himalayas. They see China as intent on the "strategic encirclement" of India through its neighbours, from Pakistan round to Sri Lanka. If India's political opposition, despite Mr Vajpayee's personal stake in relations with China, decides to play the patriotic card, Mr Dixit and Mr Dai may find it more convenient to keep on meeting amicably than to reach agreement.

Relations may now be on the point of recovery , though the " brotherhood " the giant Asian neighbours asserted in the 1950s remains a distant memory . 
 In Delhi this week , J.N. Dixit , India 's national - security advisor , and Dai Bingguo , a Chinese deputy foreign minister , held two days of talks on the border dispute . Such discussions have a history dating back to 1981 . A joint working group on the issue was formed in 1988 . It made little progress , but allowed relations to improve in other ways . Last year Atal Bihari Vajpayee's visited China and gave the talks new momentum . They were elevated from an exercise in cartographic quarrelling by officials to a " political dialogue " , intended , presumably , to reach a conclusion . This is the third round , but the first since India 's new government , led by the Congress party , took office in May. 
 There was no breakthrough , but China has been reassured that the new government wants to continue a steady improvement in ties . This has been led by business . Just a couple of years ago , Indian firms were fretting about losing market share to China . Now many see opportunities as well as threats . In the first five months of this year , Indian exports to China more than doubled compared with the same period last year , to $ 3.6 billion , while imports from China grew by more than half , to $ 1.9 billion . C. Raja Mohan , an analyst at Delhi 's Jawarhalal Nehru University , sees vast potential as relations develop . Calcutta ( now Kolkata ) , he points out , was once the port for Lhasa , capital of Tibet . 
 Regional and global politics also favour closer ties . Both countries , though keen to pursue better relations with America , are wary of its global dominance . China has moderated its traditional backing for Pakistan and its claim on Kashmir . Indeed , China has been exasperated by Pakistani provocations in Kashmir in recent years , and by the Islamic militants who sneak from Pakistan to its own Muslim - dominated western region of Xinjiang . 
 The outlines of a border deal have been clear for decades . India would cede its claim to an area of Ladakh in Kashmir , almost the size of Switzerland , occupied by China and of strategic importance to it . In return , China would accept Indian sovereignty over an area nearly three times larger , the state of Arunachal Pradesh . In each sector , some adjustments would be made . This would help spare India 's blushes at a settlement it fought to thwart , and let China say it had not accepted a border imposed by British imperialists . 
 India , a raucous democracy , would have more trouble selling such a trade - off at home . In the military and intelligence establishments some are still thankful for the God - given barrier formed by the Himalayas . They see China as intent on the " strategic encirclement " of India through its neighbours , from Pakistan round to Sri Lanka . If India 's political opposition , despite Atal Bihari Vajpayee's personal stake in relations with China , decides to play the patriotic card , Mr Dixit and Mr Dai may find it more convenient to keep on meeting amicably than to reach agreement .

text:
Truth and justice, like reconciliation, prove elusive in Gujarat
THE scar left by the pogrom directed at the Muslim minority in the Indian state of Gujarat in February and March 2002 has yet to heal. That is partly because not a single murderer has been convicted, although perhaps 2,000 people died. The state government is under pressure from local activists, human-rights groups and India's staunchly interventionist Supreme Court to see that justice is at last done. But it continues to act less like a scourge of illegal violence than its sponsor.
This week, the Supreme Court rebuked the state government's prosecutor for his failure to secure the arrest of ten of 21 Hindus accused in an infamous court case arising from the violence: the burning to death of 14 Muslims in a bakery. The accused have already been acquitted once, after witnesses withdrew their evidence. Prosecutors appealed, but in April the Supreme Court ruled that a fair retrial was impossible in Gujarat and moved the case to the neighbouring state of Maharashtra.
The state government may have reasons for subverting the judicial process. Led by Narendra Modi, a charismatic but demagogic hardliner from the Hindu-Nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), it is accused of having done little to prevent the slaughter. Many think it was complicit.
The government has, however, acted against those accused of the horrific "crime" that sparked the carnage. Using the controversial Prevention of Terrorism Act (POTA), it has charged 123 Muslims and detained nearly 100 over a fire in a train compartment, which took place in the town of Godhra. Of the 58 people asphyxiated or burned to death, many were Hindu devotees, returning from a gathering at the contested site of a temple in the holy town of Ayodhya. A Muslim mob was alleged to have doused the carriage with petrol, ignited it and locked the doors. 
Revenge for this massacre was the BJP's explanation for the slaughter that followed. Even Atal Behari Vajpayee, the BJP's leader and, at the time, prime minister, seen as a moderate, asked "Who lit the fire first?". That foreigners and the liberal English-language press in Delhi largely ignored the Godhra massacre, concentrating on the killings of Muslims--some 9-10% of Gujarat's 50m population--heightened the sense of grievance. It helped Mr Modi lead the BJP to a landslide victory in state elections in December 2002.
Yet forensic analysis and eyewitnesses have cast doubt on the government's theory of a preplanned arson attack. A hideous accident seems more likely. Last month, the railway minister in the government that came to power in Delhi in May, Laloo Prasad Yadav, announced an enquiry into the Godhra incident. 
Mr Modi's critics were encouraged by the BJP's surprise defeat in the general elections and by its relatively poor showing in Gujarat itself, which they like to interpret as a repudiation of the BJP's communal politics. Local human-rights and social-welfare groups have had a renewed burst of energy, compiling lists of demands of the new central government led by the Congress party. The government this week agreed to one, revoking POTA, but not, as petitioners had hoped, with retrospective effect. 
Harsh Mander, an activist and writer, says that if the government fails to do more it risks "missing a moment in history", when it has a chance "to make amends for past injustices". It may already be too late, however, to rebuild trust between Hindus and Muslims. The killing accelerated their segregation--a process, says Hanif Lakdawala, a prominent social worker, that is now 90% complete. 
An example is the expanding ghetto behind the Bombay Hotel in Ahmedabad, Gujarat's main city. A warren of crude redbrick houses--much of it, during the present monsoon, under water--it is now home to some 4,000 Muslim families, mostly fugitives from the 2002 violence.
One of them, Yusuf, drives an autorickshaw, a three-wheel taxi. He is still too scared to return to his old home. Just last month, depositing passengers in a Hindu district, he was recognised as a Muslim and locals threw stones at him. Two weeks ago, fresh clashes erupted in Veraval, 320km (200 miles) south-west of Ahmedabad. But in the Bombay Hotel settlement, surrounded by 4km in either direction of exclusively Muslim slum, he feels safe. Muslims complain of a tacit economic boycott; employers put job applications bearing Muslim names to one side. In response, conservative Muslim organisations are gaining influence.
Communal relations in Gujarat raise concerns far beyond the state. This month, India's film censors refused a certificate to "Final Solution", a documentary on the 2002 pogrom and its aftermath, which has won prizes at film festivals from Berlin to Zanzibar. The censors accused the film of promoting "communal disharmony". Its maker, Rakesh Sharma, says they have become politically partisan.
The BJP itself has been in some disarray since its election defeat. Some members partly blame the setback on the stigma of the Gujarat pogrom. But the BJP's more fervent supporters--who idolise Mr Modi--accuse the party of having compromised its core "Hindu" principles to court moderate support. In Gujarat itself, Mr Modi has survived, for now, a rebellion from within the local party. His job was in jeopardy not because of his hardline views but because his high-handed manner has alienated many state legislators. For this reason, many in Ahmedabad still expect him to go later this year. The debate in the BJP over how to assess his rule, however, will go on much longer. So, sadly, will its effects on Gujarat's communal relations.

text:
How well is Mahmohan Singh's new coalition government doing?
THE calendar of the world's biggest democracy is merciless. Just four months after finding itself--to universal astonishment, including its own--leading a national coalition government, India's Congress party faces another big election. On October 13th, Maharashtra, the country's richest and second most-populous state, goes to the polls. Congress officials are keen to portray the close-fought contest, where a state-level Congress-led coalition risks defeat, as a local one. Yet they also hope that the popularity of their leader, Sonia Gandhi, and of Manmohan Singh, in whose favour she renounced the prime minister's office, will win votes.
The personal standing of Mrs Gandhi and Mr Singh has not, however, afforded the government a honeymoon. Instead, from the day it took office it was beset by doubts: about how the two would share power and manage a disparate coalition; and about whether policymaking would be crippled by the need to retain the support, from outside the formal coalition, of the two Communist parties on which it relies for a parliamentary majority.
Although the stockmarket was quick to overcome its initial panic at the Communists' pivotal role (see chart), this last question has nagged most tenaciously. Far from behaving like a faithful poodle, grateful for a basket near the seat of power, the Communists have snapped terrier-like at the government's heels. Sitaram Yechury, of the bigger of the two Communist parties, even gave warning that the left's bite might be "worse than its bark". He says that the government, not the left, has picked all the fights. But all the squabbles revolve around the left's objections to the economic reforms with which Mr Singh and his team are identified. If they are heeded, policy may well be paralysed. 
The contentious issues are more than symbolic. They include privatising airports, raising the cap on foreign investment in the insurance and telecommunications industries and cutting the subsidised interest rates paid to pensioners through a provident fund. This week a new tiff blew up, over the government's intention to abolish a big irritant to potential foreign investors: a rule that gives Indian firms a veto over their foreign joint-venture partners' expansion plans.
The most perplexing storm, however, has been in the teacup of the Planning Commission. It wanted to appoint a few representatives of non-Indian bodies, like the World Bank and McKinsey, a consultancy, to consultative committees assessing the present five-year plan. The left snapped angrily. Mr Yechury says the dispute was not about ideology but the loss of sovereignty implied in inviting foreign entities on to government committees.
Senior Congress officials, however, see the complaints as an attempt by the left to appease the anti-reform instincts of many Communist party workers. A particular target is Montek Ahluwalia, the commission's boss. More than anyone, Mr Ahluwalia, who returned from a senior job at the IMF to join the government, is identified with economic liberalisation. Some Congress officials now question his political wisdom: why take on the left in a pointless battle? The end he sought has now been achieved simply by dissolving the committees, leaving the commission free to talk to everybody.
Congress leaders, however, insist that the Communists are still all bark and no bite. They point to the gulf between the ideologues in Delhi and the reformist Communist government in West Bengal, which mounts roadshows to attract foreign investment, and is closing down loss-making state enterprises. Jairam Ramesh, Congress's chief economic adviser, argues that "when push comes to shove", the left will not block some of the biggest planned reforms. Indeed, West Bengal has taken a lead in pushing for one of them: the introduction, at the fourth attempt, of a nationwide value-added tax next April.
This is the first national coalition government Congress has led, and it is not surprising there are teething troubles, especially since Congress is "cohabiting" with parties that are its biggest rivals in some states. The Communists and some coalition members need to pander to their constituencies with populist anti-reform rhetoric. But those same constituencies would be aghast if they were to bring about the fall of the government and the restoration of one led by the main opposition Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP). 
For this reason Kamal Nath, the commerce minister, claims that there could be no "better-bonded" coalition. It is true it is stronger than it sometimes looks, and stockmarket investors seem to have decided it will be able to deliver decisive policy, including some economic reform. But it has yet to prove that it has the strength to deliver the radical policies and reforms it has promised, as well as merely survive.
At least the division of labour between Mrs Gandhi and Mr Singh--she does the politics while he handles policy--seems to work. There may have been some quiet glee among those close to Mrs Gandhi at the discomfiture of Mr Ahluwalia, one of the prime minister's closest advisers. But, as yet, factional feuding is low-key.
Mr Ramesh argues that the Maharashtra election matters less for Congress than it does for the BJP. Victory would be a big boost, since the state capital Mumbai is India's financial centre and power there gives a fund-raising edge, but Congress could dismiss defeat as the usual anti-incumbent backlash. The BJP, however, is split by a tussle for the succession to its septuagenarian leaders, Atal Behari Vajpayee and L.K. Advani. It needs to win to stem a rapid slide in its fortunes; but victory will not end its internal struggles.

text:
A state election gives both big parties headaches
BEFORE India's general election in April and May, pundits were asking whether the Congress party, then in opposition, was in terminal decline. After its unforeseen victory was repeated on October 13th in an election in the state of Maharashtra, some of the very same pundits are asking the very same question about its main rival for national power, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP).
This was an election that, by the normal rules of Indian politics, the BJP and its local ally, Shiv Sena, should have won. Few governments, if any, are able to make much of a dent in the miserable poverty endured by most Indians, even in Maharashtra, the country's wealthiest state, so incumbency is a disadvantage. In Maharashtra, even Congress leaders admitted that the coalition government the party led there had performed badly. 
Yet the Congress alliance won 141 of the 288 seats, compared with 117 for the BJP and Shiv Sena. For Shiv Sena, which has a vile record of demagoguery and anti-Muslim thuggery, this was a serious setback. The party's rabble-rouser-in-chief, Bal Thackeray, is in poor health and could not campaign. His son and nephew are competing for the succession. Optimists interpret this year's elections as showing that the old message of communal hatred is losing impact in favour of the Indian trinity of livelihood issues--roads, water and electricity.
The BJP, too, is a Hindu-nationalist party, but is increasingly split between moderates, who want it to broaden its appeal, and advocates of sticking close to Hindutva, the party's original Hindu ideology. A few hardliners have already quit, seeking to revive the Jan Sangh, a party from which the BJP is itself descended. The Jan Sangh's Prafull Goradia accuses the BJP of "giving up its reason for existence".
Defeat in Maharashtra has now dented the illusion the BJP has clung to since the general election: that the Congress-led coalition would speedily collapse. It has also uncovered the bitterness of the power struggle among its second-rung leaders, those waiting to take over from Atal Behari Vajpayee, prime minister until May, and his deputy, Lal Krishna Advani. Both men are in their late 70s and, surely, unlikely to lead the party into the next election if the present government lasts anything like its full five-year term.
After the Maharashtra result, the party's president, Venkaiah Naidu, resigned. But as Rajdeep Sardesai, of NDTV, a television news channel, cuttingly put it, the old order changeth, yielding place to the older. Mr Advani, the party's battle-hardened war-horse, who led its rapid march to national prominence in the early 1990s, saddled up again, for his third stint as president.
Congress's glee at its main rival's disarray was tempered by troubles of its own. It won fewer seats in Maharashtra than did its coalition partner, the Nationalist Congress Party (NCP), led by Sharad Pawar, the agriculture minister in the central coalition. The two parties then squabbled bitterly about who should lead the new state government. 
The NCP was formed as a breakaway from Congress in 1999 in protest at the "dynastic and authoritarian" appointment of Sonia Gandhi, who was born in Italy, as its leader--a post that Mr Pawar had coveted. Some analysts, pointing to Mr Pawar's hostile past relations with Congress, foresee troubles ahead at the centre, as smaller parties, such as his, dream of a "third front" coalition without either of the two big parties. For now that is more of an arithmetic possibility than a real threat. That some see it as more of a danger than the BJP is a measure of how fast that party's fortunes have fallen.
Caption: Has Pawar's time come?

text:
India should know better than to expect Kashmiri gratitude
LIKE his predecessor, Atal Behari Vajpayee, India's prime minister, Manmohan Singh, came to Kashmir bearing gifts and a message of peace. He spoke on November 17th to a bused-in crowd behind the same bullet-proof glass in the same cricket stadium in the capital, Srinagar, where 19 months earlier Mr Vajpayee had extended "the hand of friendship" to Pakistan. Mr Singh tried something no less ambitious: to make friends with the Kashmiris themselves. Their reaction was churlish. But in the chilly autumn sun, prospects for peace seemed brighter than they dreamed possible when Mr Vajpayee spoke through April drizzle.
War was not far away, however. Before Mr Singh's speech Indian soldiers had had a three-hour shoot-out with two militants. They had somehow managed to hide themselves in a derelict building overlooking the stadium. Tens of thousands of Indian soldiers, Kashmiri and foreign militants and civilians have died in 15 years of insurgency against Indian rule.
Mr Singh had delivered his most important gifts in advance. A few days earlier, he had announced that India would withdraw some of its troops from Kashmir. This was the first such public promise from India since the uprising began. There are an estimated 500,000 soldiers, paramilitary forces and police in Kashmir, and the withdrawal may yet turn out to be small and symbolic. But even some separatists admitted it was an important symbol.
Also sparking some Kashmiri hopes, Mr Singh's government had said it would be prepared to consider new proposals for resolving the 57-year dispute with Pakistan over Kashmir if they were formally tabled. This may happen on November 23rd, when Pakistan's prime minister, Shaukat Aziz, will be in Delhi. His boss, General Pervez Musharraf, last month floated some vague but radical-sounding ideas, perhaps heralding big concessions.
The government probably hoped these positive signals would distract Kashmiris from protests over the latest alleged atrocity by Indian forces: the rape of a woman and her ten-year old daughter. It may also have hoped to persuade moderate separatist leaders to meet Mr Singh during his visit. The separatists, however, refused, demanding that the government first allow them to visit Pakistan to talk to militant leaders there. In his speech, Mr Singh made a moving appeal for unconditional dialogue, but did not yield to this demand. 
For some Kashmiris, that was one of several disappointments. They had hoped for other political concessions, such as the release of detainees, or even a unilateral ceasefire from Indian forces. Instead, they heard a promise of massive central-government economic aid and a "new beginning" for the territory. Mr Singh ruled out any redrawing of international borders, or anything which smacks of a further division of India along religious lines. 
Yet even separatists such as Umar Farooq, spiritual leader of the Kashmir valley's Sunni Muslims, accept that Mr Singh is a "decent fellow", and that there are some grounds for optimism. It was always unrealistic for Kashmiris to expect Mr Singh to come with dramatic political concessions. But the prime minister's advisers were equally over-optimistic if they expected Kashmiris to think much of Mr Singh's undoubtedly sincere pledge of "peace with dignity".
